questions.text:
A 34-year-old woman comes to the physician because she has not had her menses for 6 months. She has also had milky-white discharge from her nipples, frequent headaches, and blurry vision during the past 4 months. Menses had previously occurred at regular 30-day intervals and lasted for 4–5 days with moderate flow. She takes no medications. She has two children who are healthy and attend middle school. She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 68 kg (145 lb); BMI is 26 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Pelvic examination shows vaginal atrophy and a normal uterus. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of electrolytes, creatinine, and glucose are within the reference range. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Serum studies are most likely to show which of the following sets of findings in this patient?



Prolactin
Follicle-stimulating hormone
Luteinizing hormone



A
Normal
decreased
decreased


B
Decreased
increased
increased


C
Increased
increased
increased


D
Decreased
decreased
decreased


E
Normal
increased
increased


F
Increased
decreased
decreased
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The constellation of normal prolactin level, decreased follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), and decreased luteinizing hormone (LH) could be seen in a nonfunctioning pituitary adenoma because gonadotropic cells often respond to mass effect earlier than other cell types, e.g., those producing prolactin. A pituitary tumor of any kind can cause compressive symptoms (e.g., headache, visual changes), and this patient's amenorrhea and vaginal atrophy do suggest decreased FSH, resulting in low estrogen levels. However, her galactorrhea would suggest another hormonal abnormality.

B) INCORRECT:

Decreased prolactin, elevated follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), and increased luteinizing hormone (LH) could be explained by a functioning gonadotroph adenoma, which may induce hypopituitarism via mass effect. A pituitary tumor of any kind can cause compressive symptoms, which would explain this patient's sudden headaches and blurry vision. However, her estrogen level would be normal-to-high in the case of increased FSH secretion by the adenoma, which would not explain her vaginal atrophy — a sign of low estrogen levels. Also, her galactorrhea would indicate a different hormonal abnormality.

C) INCORRECT:

The combination of elevated prolactin, follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), and luteinizing hormone (LH) might be seen if a functioning gonadotropic adenoma grew large enough to cause impingement of the infundibular stalk, leading to mild hyperprolactinemia secondary to the interruption of the tonic inhibitory effect of hypothalamic dopamine on the secretion of prolactin (disconnection hyperprolactinemia). Hyperprolactinemia can cause galactorrhea. However, elevated FSH leads to a normal/high estrogen and would not be consistent with vaginal atrophy, which is a sign of decreased estrogen.

D) INCORRECT:

The constellation of decreased prolactin, follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), and luteinizing hormone (LH) is seen in some forms of hypopituitarism, e.g., in a patient with a slow-growing, nonsecretory adenoma that compresses the regular hormone-secreting cells of the pituitary gland. A pituitary tumor could explain this patient's headaches and vision problems and decreased FSH could cause decreased estrogen levels, which would explain the vaginal atrophy and oligomenorrhea. However, her galactorrhea is highly suggestive of a different hormonal abnormality.

E) INCORRECT:

Normal prolactin, elevated follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), and elevated luteinizing hormone (LH) could be caused by a hormone-secreting gonadotropic adenoma. Although a pituitary tumor of any kind can cause compressive symptoms (e.g., headache, blurry vision), and increased FSH can cause amenorrhea (via ovarian hyperstimulation), the described constellation of hormones would not explain this patient's galactorrhea nor the vaginal atrophy.

F) CORRECT:

Prolactinomas are the most common cause of hyperprolactinemia. Hyperprolactinemia has an inhibitory effect on GnRH (gonadotropin-releasing hormone), which leads to a decrease in LH and FSH (luteinizing hormone and follicle-stimulating hormone) and subsequently a decline in estrogen and testosterone, resulting in amenorrhea/oligomenorrhea, vaginal atrophy, and endometrial atrophy. Hyperprolactinemia has a direct tropic effect on breast tissue and triggers lactation, explaining this patient's galactorrhea — a finding that is seen in 80% of premenopausal women with hyperprolactinemia. A pituitary tumor of any kind can cause compressive symptoms, leading to bitemporal hemianopsia and/or palsy of the adjacent cranial nerves III, IV, or VI. The best next step in the diagnosis of suspected pituitary adenoma is a brain MRI with contrast. First-line treatment for prolactinomas is dopamine agonists (e.g., cabergoline), which inhibit prolactin secretion and induce shrinkage of the tumor.
questions.hint: The presence of amenorrhea, galactorrhea, and vaginal atrophy in a woman with new-onset headaches and blurry vision should raise suspicion of a prolactinoma.

questions.text:
A 36-year-old woman comes to the gynecologist because of a 4-month history of irregular menstrual cycles. Menses occur at irregular 15 to 45-day intervals and last 1–2 days with minimal flow. She also reports a milk-like discharge from her nipples for 3 months, accompanied by fatigue and muscle and joint pain. She does not have abdominal pain, fever, or headache. She has recently gained 2.5 kg (5.5 lb) of weight. She was diagnosed with schizophrenia and started on aripiprazole by a psychiatrist 8 months ago. She has hypothyroidism but has not been taking levothyroxine for 6 months. She does not smoke or consume alcohol. She appears healthy and anxious. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows vaginal atrophy. Visual field and skin examination are normal. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
12.7 g/dL


Serum



Glucose
88 mg/dL


Creatinine
0.7 mg/dL


Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH)
16.3 μU/mL


Cortisol (8 AM)
18 μg/dL


Prolactin
88 ng/mL


Urinalysis is normal. An x-ray of the chest and ultrasound of the pelvis show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the nipple discharge in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with thyrotropic pituitary adenomas have increased levels of TSH and clinical features of hyperthyroidism (secondary to increased TSH) such as weight loss, heat intolerance, diarrhea, and/or tachycardia. Large thyrotropic adenomas (> 10 mm) can present with features of hyperprolactinemia because they compress the infundibular stalk and result in an interruption of the tonic inhibitory effect of hypothalamic dopamine on the secretion of prolactin (disconnection hyperprolactinemia). However, since this patient is hypothyroid, thyrotropic pituitary adenoma is an unlikely diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Ectopic prolactin production is a paraneoplastic syndrome that occurs in certain tumors such as lung and/or renal cell carcinoma. However, this patient does not have any clinical features suggesting malignancy. Also, ectopic prolactin production is extremely rare when compared with other forms of paraneoplastic hormone secretion (e.g., ectopic ACTH production).

C) INCORRECT:

Typical antipsychotics (and to a lesser extent, atypical antipsychotics) frequently cause hyperprolactinemia by blocking D2 dopamine receptors of the tuberoinfundibular region in the hypothalamus. However, aripiprazole is a unique atypical antipsychotic drug because it does not cause hyperprolactinemia. Aripiprazole acts as an agonist under hypodopaminergic conditions (thereby preventing hyperprolactinemia) but antagonizes D2 receptors under hyperdopaminergic conditions (thus retaining its antipsychotic effect).

D) INCORRECT:

Cushing disease could present with symptoms of hypercortisolism such as muscle pain and menstrual irregularities. However, the normal levels of early morning cortisol and the absence of hypertension and hyperglycemia make Cushing disease an unlikely diagnosis.

E) CORRECT:

Increased TSH in a hypothyroid patient (e.g., fatigue, recent weight gain, and myalgia) who has not been taking their levothyroxine medication suggests primary hypothyroidism. In primary hypothyroidism, decreased T3 and T4 levels stimulate the secretion of thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH) by the hypothalamus, which in turn increases TSH release by the anterior pituitary. In addition to increasing TSH production, excessive TRH also stimulates the lactotroph cells of the anterior pituitary to release prolactin, thus resulting in a state of hyperprolactinemia.

F) INCORRECT:

Prolactinomas are the most common cause of hyperprolactinemia. However, prolactin levels in a patient with a prolactinoma are usually > 200 ng/mL. A prolactin level < 100 ng/mL in this patient suggests a different cause for hyperprolactinemia. Additionally, most secretory pituitary adenomas do not secrete multiple pituitary hormones, and prolactinomas that secrete TSH are extremely rare. Increased TSH levels suggest another diagnosis.
questions.hint: Galactorrhea and irregular menstrual cycles are suggestive of hyperprolactinemia.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl is brought to the physician because she has not yet attained menarche. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. She is 168 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 63 kg (139 lb); BMI is 22 kg/m2. Examination shows normal breast development. Scant axillary hair is present. Abdominal examination shows a firm, nontender left inguinal mass. Pelvic examination shows a blind vaginal pouch. Ultrasonography does not show a uterus or ovaries. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A defect in the SRY gene on chromosome Y results in Swyer syndrome, which manifests with primary amenorrhea and absent or atretic ovaries on ultrasound. However, normal development of axillary hair would occur (due to adrenal androgens), and a uterus would be present. Also, breast development would be impaired, and palpable testes would not be present.

B) INCORRECT:

Mullerian duct agenesis results in primary amenorrhea, an absent uterus on ultrasound, and a blind vaginal pouch due to vaginal atresia. However, the ovaries would be present. Axillary hair growth would also be normal since primary amenorrhea in patients with Mullerian duct agenesis is the result of an anatomical defect and not a hormonal one.

C) INCORRECT:

Five-alpha-reductase deficiency can manifest with primary amenorrhea, female external genitalia with an inguinal testis, and the absence of ovaries and the uterus on ultrasound. However, breast development does not usually occur, and patients would typically have some degree of virilization (e.g., hirsutism, clitoromegaly) at the time of puberty.
Image Description:

Individuals with 5-alpha reductase deficiency are karyotypically male but often grow up with a female gender identity. At birth, external male genitalia and the prostate are underdeveloped because these organs are dependent on dihydrotestosterone for in-utero development. During puberty, testosterone levels increase, resulting in the development of secondary male sexual characteristics, and some individuals undergo a change in gender identity.

D) INCORRECT:

A form of sex chromosomal mosaicism called mixed gonadal dysgenesis (characterized by a 45, XO/XY karyotype) may result in a single inguinal testis, with features of Turner syndrome such as primary amenorrhea and absent or atretic ovaries on ultrasound. Breast development, however, would also be impaired, and a unicornuate uterus or a fallopian tube remnant would be seen on ultrasound on the side without the testicle. Other features would also be seen, such as neck webbing, a low hairline, short stature, shield chest, lymphedema, intellectual disability, congenital heart defects, and/or renal anomalies.

E) INCORRECT:

Sex chromosomal monosomy is the underlying pathophysiology of Turner syndrome, which can manifest with primary amenorrhea, normal external genitalia with a patent introitus, and atretic or absent ovaries on ultrasound. However, breast development would be impaired, an inguinal testicle and vaginal atresia would not be expected, and the uterus would be seen on ultrasound. Other features would also be seen, such as neck webbing, a low hairline, short stature, a cubitus valgus defect, shield chest, lymphedema, intellectual disability, congenital heart defects, and/or renal anomalies.

F) CORRECT:

Patients with androgen insensitivity syndrome (AIS) are karyotypically male (XY). The Y chromosome results in the formation of the testes (instead of the ovaries) from the undifferentiated fetal gonad. The uterus does not develop because the anti-Mullerian hormone secreted by the testes causes Mullerian duct atresia. However, the genital tubercle in AIS is not responsive to testosterone, so masculinization of the external genitalia does not occur. AIS also results in a failure of the cranial suspensory ligament to regress, meaning the testes remain in the inguinal canal or abdomen instead of the perineal region. Patients are born with female external genitalia and are generally raised as women. At the time of puberty, axillary and pubic hair growth is also absent or decreased since cutaneous androgen receptors lack sensitivity. Breast development occurs despite the absence of ovaries since aromatase in adipose tissue converts androgens produced by the inguinal testes to estradiol.

Hormonal analysis in patients with AIS shows elevated LH levels due to insensitivity of the pituitary gland to androgen and possibly elevated testosterone levels due to stimulation of the Leydig cells by LH. The diagnosis is confirmed by genetic testing, which shows a mutation in the AR gene on chromosome Xq. Patients with complete AIS usually have a female gender identity.
questions.hint: This patient's serum luteinizing hormone (LH) and testosterone levels will both be elevated.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl comes to the physician with her mother because of intermittent abdominal cramps, fatigue, and increased urination over the past 3 months. She has no history of serious illness. She reports that she has not yet had her first menstrual period. Her mother states that she receives mostly A and B grades in school and is very active in school athletics. Her mother has type 2 diabetes mellitus and her maternal aunt has polycystic ovary syndrome. Her only medication is a daily multivitamin. The patient is 150 cm (4 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 50 kg (110 lb); BMI is 22 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. A grade 2/6 early systolic murmur is heard best over the pulmonic area and increases with inspiration. The abdomen is diffusely tender to palpation. Breast and pubic hair development are at Tanner stage 5. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Morning serum cortisol is used in the diagnosis of adrenal insufficiency, which can manifest with amenorrhea, fatigue, and gastrointestinal symptoms such as abdominal pain. However, urinary symptoms are not typically seen in adrenal insufficiency. Additionally, this patient lacks other features of adrenal insufficiency (e.g., weight loss, sugar craving, loss of axillary and pubic hair, hyperpigmentation). A different diagnosis is more likely at this point and needs to be excluded first.

B) INCORRECT:

Urinalysis and urine culture are used in the diagnosis of urinary tract infections (UTIs), which can cause increased urination, abdominal pain, and fatigue. Primary amenorrhea, however, suggests a different cause for this patient's constellation of features. Additionally, this patient lacks other typical irritative lower urinary symptoms like urinary urgency and dysuria. A different step in diagnosis is more appropriate at this point.

C) INCORRECT:

Serum FSH and LH levels are used in the workup of primary amenorrhea. However, they are not the first step in the diagnostic approach of a patient with primary amenorrhea. Additionally, this patient's clinical features already point to a specific cause of primary amenorrhea, for which a different diagnostic test is more appropriate.

D) CORRECT:

Measurement of β-hCG in the serum or urine is the first step in management if pregnancy is suspected. Pregnancy is detectable 6–9 days after fertilization in serum (or ∼ 14 days after fertilization in urine). Amenorrhea (primary or secondary), polyuria, and fatigue are among the most common signs of early pregnancy; additional signs and symptoms include nausea, vomiting, breast enlargement and tenderness, and weight gain. This 16-year-old girl's presentation raises suspicion for pregnancy, and although she reports that she has not had her first menstrual period yet, pregnancy should be ruled out first before performing other diagnostic steps.

E) INCORRECT:

Karyotyping should be performed if a chromosomal abnormality such as Turner syndrome is suspected. This patient does not present with the typical Turner syndrome features such as a webbed neck and widely spaced nipples. Although Turner syndrome is among the most common causes of primary amenorrhea, another test should be performed initially.

F) INCORRECT:

Gonadotropin-releasing hormone stimulation testing in pediatrics is most commonly performed in the diagnostics for precocious or delayed puberty. Although this patient presents with primary amenorrhea, other tests should be performed before initiating puberty diagnostics.
questions.hint: This 16-year-old girl presents with fatigue, polyuria, primary amenorrhea, and abdominal cramps. This constellation of features indicates a possible pregnancy. The systolic heart murmur may be caused by a hyperdynamic state.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl comes to the physician because of right lower abdominal pain for 1 day. She describes the pain as 5 out of 10 in intensity. Over the past 5 months, she has had similar episodes of pain that occur once a month and last 1 to 2 days. Menses occur at regular 28-day intervals with moderate intensity and last 5 to 6 days. Her last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago. She has been sexually active with two male partners in the past and uses condoms for contraception. She tested negative for sexually transmitted infections on her last visit 6 months ago. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 76/min, and blood pressure is 126/60 mm Hg. On abdominal examination, there is mild tenderness to palpation in the right lower quadrant; no masses are palpated. Bimanual pelvic examination shows mildly tender and mildly swollen right adnexa. Laboratory studies are within the reference ranges. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Pelvic ultrasonography shows a follicle with irregular margins in the right ovary and a trace of anechoic free fluid in the pouch of Douglas. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Combined oral contraceptive pills and NSAIDs as needed are used in the treatment of endometriosis. Endometriosis, for which family history is a risk factor, may manifest with cyclic pelvic pain and tenderness. However, the pain typically occurs before menses rather than midcycle and is usually accompanied by dyspareunia and premenstrual or postmenstrual bleeding. Furthermore, physical examination in endometriosis would likely show rectovaginal tenderness and multiple adnexal masses, which are not seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Laparoscopic adnexal detorsion is the treatment for ovarian torsion, which may manifest with unilateral lower abdominal and/or pelvic pain and tenderness with normal laboratory findings. However, patients typically present with sudden-onset severe abdominal pain that is accompanied by nausea and vomiting rather than episodic midcycle pain. Furthermore, pelvic ultrasound would most likely show an edematous, enlarged ovary and a thickened fallopian tube.
Image Description:

Ultrasound pelvis (ovary; with color Doppler)

The ovary is enlarged, rounded, and heterogeneous. No blood flow is visible within the color Doppler box (green outline).

Arrowhead: example of follicle

C) CORRECT:

Mittelschmerz is a common benign phenomenon in women of reproductive age that is caused by physiologic enlargement and rupture of the follicular cyst during ovulation, which leads to the release of small amount of intraperitoneal fluid and subsequent peritoneal irritation. The pain is self-limited and usually subsides within a few hours to two days. Patients should be reassured and given symptomatic treatment with NSAIDs as needed.

If symptoms do not resolve with NSAIDs, combined oral contraceptive pills (COCPs) can be used in the treatment of mittelschmerz. COCPs inhibit follicular development and subsequent ovulation, preventing the recurrence of mittelschmerz.
Image Description:

The menstrual cycle consists of two phases: the follicular and the luteal phase. The onset of menses marks the beginning of the follicular phase, which usually lasts 12–14 days but may be variable. The luteal phase begins on the day of ovulation and lasts 14 days.

During the follicular phase, FSH and LH stimulate the development of several follicles, one of which develops as the dominant follicle into the Graafian follicle. An LH surge initiates ovulation. As the oocyte reaches the fallopian tube, the ruptured follicle transforms into the corpus luteum, which produces progesterone. If no pregnancy occurs, the corpus luteum regresses and the progesterone level drops. This drop induces vasospasms in the uterine spiral arteries, ischemia, and sloughing off of the functional endometrial layer, which leads to menstrual bleeding (menstrual phase). During the proliferative phase, the endometrium is built up again in preparation for oocyte implantation during the secretory phase.

1: stages of follicle development; 2: hormone levels; 3: phases of the endometrial cycle; 4: development of the endometrium during the cycle

D) INCORRECT:

Intravenous antibiotic therapy (e.g., cefoxitin plus doxycycline) is indicated for tuboovarian abscess, which may manifest with unilateral lower abdominal and/or pelvic pain and tender adnexal enlargement. However, patients typically present with signs of infection (e.g., fever, leukocytosis), and pelvic ultrasound shows a complex multilocular mass rather than a ruptured follicular cyst. Furthermore, cyclical pelvic pain over several months is not characteristic of tuboovarian abscess.

E) INCORRECT:

Combined oral contraceptive pills are the preferred treatment for polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) in patients who do not wish to conceive. PCOS typically manifests with menstrual irregularities, signs of hyperandrogenism, and enlarged or polycystic ovaries on ultrasound. This patient has normal menstrual cycles and no evidence of hyperandrogenism (e.g., hirsutism, acne). The right ovarian enlargement is likely the result of physiologic follicular cyst rupture.

F) INCORRECT:

Serial serum β-hCG concentration measurements are part of the expectant management of ectopic pregnancy. An ectopic pregnancy (EP) that is located in a fallopian tube often manifests with unilateral pelvic pain and tenderness. The pain usually occurs 4–6 weeks after the last menstrual period, and patients may experience vaginal bleeding, which can be mistaken for menstruation. However, this patient has recurrent midcycle pain and does not have further signs of EP, such as breast tenderness and frequent urination. Furthermore, the negative urine pregnancy test makes an ectopic pregnancy highly unlikely.
questions.hint: This patient has regular menses and experiences recurrent, unilateral, lower abdominal pain during midcycle. Ultrasound shows a ruptured simple follicular cyst.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother because she has not attained menarche. She has no history of serious illness. She is at the 50th percentile for height and weight. Examination shows no glandular breast tissue and no pubic hair development. Pelvic examination shows no abnormalities. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The GnRH stimulation test is the gold standard for identifying central precocious puberty. This patient lacks signs of puberty such as menarche and breast development and requires further evaluation of primary amenorrhea.

B) INCORRECT:

All patients who have not reached menarche by the age of 16 years or have not developed secondary sexual characteristics (breasts, pubic hair) by the age of 13 years must be evaluated for primary amenorrhea. Further tests should be initiated to identify correctable causes and initiate treatment, if necessary.

C) INCORRECT:

The progesterone challenge test is indicated in suspected gonadotropin deficiency (low FSH, LH, and estrogen). Gonadotropin levels of this patient have not been measured yet, therefore, another step is more appropriate at this point.

D) INCORRECT:

An MRI of the brain is only indicated if FSH levels are low and a hypothalamic or pituitary disease (e.g., pituitary tumor) is suspected, which could cause hypogonadotropic hypogonadism and subsequent primary amenorrhea. This patient does not present with additional symptoms of a process in the sella region, such as headaches, vision changes, or any other signs of hypothalamic-pituitary dysfunction.

E) CORRECT:

The evaluation of primary amenorrhea starts with a pelvic examination and a pregnancy test to rule out pregnancy. If pelvic examination confirms the presence of a uterus, serum FSH level should be assessed. A high serum FSH level indicates gonadal dysgenesis, most commonly due to chromosomal aberrations, e.g., in Turner syndrome (45,XO). Causes of a low serum FSH level include constitutional growth delay, functional growth delay (e.g., due to inflammatory bowel disease or chronic kidney disease), and hypothalamic-pituitary disorders (e.g., hemochromatosis, injury, Kallmann syndrome). Further testing depends on the suspected etiology and includes serum TSH and prolactin levels to rule out uncommon causes of primary amenorrhea (e.g., hyperprolactinemia due to prolactinoma, hypothyroidism).

In patients with blind or absent vagina on pelvic examination, a pelvic ultrasound should be performed to visualize internal reproductive organs. Congenital reproductive outflow tract obstruction (e.g., imperforate hymen) should be considered if a uterus is present. In patients without a uterus on ultrasound, serum testosterone levels and karyotyping are used to determine the underlying pathology (e.g., Mullerian agenesis, androgen insensitivity syndrome).

Depending on the result of the serum FSH studies, the working diagnosis for this patient could be either gonadal dysgenesis (e.g., Swyer syndrome) or a hypothalamic-pituitary disorder (e.g., normosmic isolated GnRH deficiency). Functional or constitutional growth delays are unlikely as the patient is in the 50th percentile for weight and height.

F) INCORRECT:

Measurement of serum free and total testosterone and dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate concentrations is indicated in suspected hyperandrogenism (e.g., patients with male pattern baldness, hirsutism, and acne). Causes include polycystic ovary syndrome, ovarian or adrenal tumors, congenital adrenal hyperplasia, and Cushing syndrome. This patient shows no features of a hyperandrogenic state and therefore requires a different test.
questions.hint: Absent or incomplete development of secondary sexual characteristics by the age of 14 years in boys or 13 years in girls indicates delayed puberty. This delay can be constitutional, secondary to underlying conditions, or due to hypogonadism.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl comes to the physician because of episodic lower abdominal pain for 5 months. The pain starts a few hours before her menses and lasts for 2–3 days. Ibuprofen helped reduce the pain in the first months but has no effect now. She has missed a couple of days at school because of severe pain. Menarche was at the age of 14 years, and menses occur at regular 29-day intervals. She is sexually active with one male partner and uses condoms inconsistently. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows normal external genitalia. The uterus is nontender, and there are no palpable masses. Speculum examination shows scant clear discharge in vaginal vault; the cervix appears normal. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Diagnostic laparoscopy with biopsy can be used to confirm the diagnosis of endometriosis, which can cause secondary dysmenorrhea. However, this patient's symptoms are consistent with primary dysmenorrhea, so diagnostic laparoscopy is not indicated.

B) INCORRECT:

Empiric treatment with cefoxitin and doxycycline is indicated in suspected pelvic inflammatory disease, which is most commonly caused by infection with Chlamydia trachomatis and/or Neisseria gonorrhea. Although this patient uses condoms inconsistently and experiences pelvic pain, she does not have other features of a sexually transmitted infection, such as uterine, adnexal, or cervical motion tenderness, urethral or vaginal discharge, or fever. This patient's scant, clear discharge is consistent with physiologic leukorrhea. In addition, her pain is episodic and coincides with her menses, which suggests another cause.

C) INCORRECT:

Pelvic ultrasonography is indicated to rule out organic causes of suspected secondary dysmenorrhea, such as pelvic infection and endometriosis. This patient's physical examination shows no abnormalities (e.g., rectovaginal tenderness, adnexal masses), and she has no history that suggests secondary dysmenorrhea (e.g., amenorrhea, dyspareunia). This patient most likely has primary dysmenorrhea, for which another step in management is more appropriate at this time.

D) CORRECT:

Primary dysmenorrhea is common in adolescent women and is likely caused by increased production of endometrial prostaglandins (PGF2α), which leads to hyperactive uterine contractions and/or uterine vasoconstriction. As primary dysmenorrhea occurs in the absence of any underlying medical condition, no further diagnostic steps are necessary when the condition is suspected. Treatment with NSAIDs and/or a combined hormonal contraceptive should be offered to stabilize hormone levels and relieve pain. Another benefit of oral contraceptives is the alleviation of PMS symptoms.

Given this patient's history of unprotected sex, she should also be counseled on safer sex practices and offered testing for sexually transmitted infections.

E) INCORRECT:

Urinalysis is indicated in suspected cystitis, which may also present with lower abdominal pain and often occurs in sexually active women. However, other clinical findings such as dysuria, urinary urgency, and frequency are missing and the patient's pain is episodic and coincides with her menses.
questions.hint: In a patient without features that suggest secondary dysmenorrhea, pain that manifests shortly before or during menses and lasts for 1–3 days is consistent with primary dysmenorrhea.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl comes to the physician because of excessive flow and duration of her menses. Since menarche a year ago, menses have occurred at irregular intervals and lasted 8–9 days. Her last menstrual period was 5 weeks ago with passage of clots. She has no family or personal history of serious illness and takes no medications. She is at the 50th percentile for height and 20th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma in the genital region, or sarcoma botryoides, may also cause menorrhagia. However, it primarily occurs in females younger than 8 years of age and is very rare.

B) INCORRECT:

Highly vascularized endometrial polyps may also cause menorrhagia. However, patients usually also have a history of irregular spotting and bleeding in between menstrual periods and are in their 40s or 50s.

C) INCORRECT:

Decreased thyroxine production (hypothyroidism) may also cause menorrhagia. However, this patient is missing additional symptoms of hypometabolism such as weight gain, cold intolerance, dry skin, hair loss, fatigue, and constipation.

D) CORRECT:

Most cases of menorrhagia within the first two years after menarche are due to an immature hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis and subsequent lack of cyclic endometrial stimulation due to inadequate gonadotropin production. As a result, there are constant, noncyclical levels of estrogen that stimulate endometrial proliferation leading to painless, irregular bleeding, usually including periods of both amenorrhea and prolonged and/or heavy bleeding. Treatment usually includes oral contraceptives or NSAIDs. Other causes for menorrhagia in adolescents include pregnancy and miscarriage, coagulation disorders, pelvic inflammatory disease, intrauterine devices, or underlying structural pelvic pathologies, for which there are no signs in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Menorrhagia in endometritis generally occurs in between cycles. Further signs of infection such as fever, lower abdominal pain and tenderness, abnormal discharge, and a history of sexually transmitted diseases are missing in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

Coagulation disorders (e.g., von Willebrand disease) should be considered in adolescents with heavy menses from menarche onset, severe anemia secondary to menstrual bleeding, and/or a personal or family history of bleeding, easy bruising, and/or epistaxis. This patient lacks a family history and other signs of bleeding diathesis. Furthermore, irregular menstrual periods are not a typical sign of von Willebrand disease.

G) INCORRECT:

Patients with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) most commonly present with oligo- or amenorrhea, and/or irregular cycle length due to ovulatory dysfunction. In addition, high androgen levels in patients with PCOS typically result in hirsutism, acne, and obesity.

H) INCORRECT:

Uterine fibroids are a potential cause of menorrhagia. However, they are more common in women 30–40 years of age and typically manifest with pelvic pressure, pain, and a bulky mass palpable on examination of the uterus. Moreover, this patient lacks risk factors for uterine fibroids such as African American descent, high consumption of alcohol and red meat, and a family history of leiomyoma.
questions.hint: The most common cause of menorrhagia in postmenarchal adolescents are alternating ovulatory and anovulatory cycles due to an immature hypothalamic–pituitary–ovarian axis.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of a 10-day history of vaginal bleeding. The flow is heavy with the passage of clots. Since menarche 1 year ago, menses have occurred at irregular 26- to 32-day intervals and last 3 to 6 days. Her last menstrual period was 4 weeks ago. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 106/70 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows vaginal bleeding. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Her hemoglobin is 13.1 g/dL. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral or IV tranexamic acid is a second-line agent used for treating blood loss in acute AUB when other options have failed. Tranexamic acid acts within 2–3 hours of administration and should not be used in women at a high risk of thrombosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Minimally invasive endometrial ablation is the preferred approach in hemodynamically stable women for whom medical therapy for AUB is unsuccessful or contraindicated, but it should only be performed in patients who do not wish to bear any more children. It provides long-term improvement of uterine bleeding symptoms by destroying a thin layer of the endometrium (e.g., with extreme cold, heat, or radiofrequency energy). Hysteroscopy prior to ablation may be useful for identifying and treating intrauterine structural abnormalities (e.g., polyps or fibroids).

C) INCORRECT:

Transcatheter uterine artery embolization is the first-line therapy in women with AUB due to uterine arteriovenous malformation (AVM) that can be identified on color Doppler ultrasound. Uterine AVMs are very rare and can be congenital or acquired. Acquired uterine AVMs should be suspected in women with profuse intermittent bleeding after uterine surgery (e.g., dilation and curettage, cesarean section). This patient has no history of surgical procedures performed on the uterus or profuse bleeding during menses since menarche (in keeping with congenital uterine AVM), making an AVM unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Dilation and uterine curettage with concomitant hysteroscopy is the preferred approach in hemodynamically unstable women with severe AUB after immediate supportive measures (e.g., fluid resuscitation, blood transfusion) have been implemented. It is both diagnostic and therapeutic (i.e., used to identify intrauterine pathologies, take tissue samples, remove excess uterine lining) and preserves fertility as well. If performed rapidly, it may decrease bleeding in less than an hour.
Image Description:

A gynecological procedure in which the cervix is widened using dilators of increasing diameters (left image) in order to allow insertion of a curette into the uterus for therapeutic or diagnostic tissue removal (right image).

E) CORRECT:

Administration of high-dose oral conjugated estrogen is the treatment of choice in hemodynamically stable women with acute AUB, irrespective of the underlying cause. High levels of estrogen trigger rapid growth of the endometrium and thereby stop sudden, heavy bleeding from the uterine surface. Surgical treatment is needed if the patient does not respond to medical treatment or is hemodynamically unstable, bleeding is severe, medical management is contraindicated, or the underlying medical condition requires surgical repair. Conjugated estrogen therapy is contraindicated in women with breast cancer and/or those at a high risk of thrombosis.

F) INCORRECT:

An intrauterine tamponade (e.g., intrauterine balloon or gauze packing) would be the initial step to decrease severe bleeding in a hemodynamically unstable woman with acute AUB. A tamponade, in addition to intravenous fluids and blood transfusions, serves to stabilize the patient until definitive therapy can be administered.
questions.hint: Acute abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB) in a girl who attained menarche only one year ago is most likely caused by anovulation due to an immature hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis. Anovulation leads to a deficit in progesterone production, while unopposed estrogen continues to cause abnormal growth of the endometrial lining and vessels. Spontaneous bleeding may result from sloughing of the endometrial lining. If increasing estrogen triggers negative feedback in the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis, a drop in FSH/LH and estrogen levels leads to a sudden loss of endometrium that can cause heavy and prolonged bleeding.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl comes to the physician because of episodic pelvic pain radiating to her back and thighs for 4 months. The pain occurs a few hours before her menstrual period and lasts for 2 days. She has been taking ibuprofen, which has provided some relief. Menses have occurred at regular 28-day intervals since menarche at the age of 12 years and last for 5 to 6 days. She is sexually active with two male partners and uses condoms inconsistently. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Endometrial sloughing and uterine contractions mediated by prostaglandin
Endometriotic cell implants in the ovaries, fallopian tubes, or cervix
Activation of lymphatic cells in the intestinal walls and local tissue damage
Ascending infection of the uterus, fallopian tubes, ovaries, or surrounding tissue
Endometrial tissue within the uterine wall
Ascending infection of the urinary tract
Hormone-sensitive smooth muscle tumor of the myometrium

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Primary dysmenorrhea is the most common gynecological complaint among adolescent females. The condition is most likely caused by an increased production of endometrial prostaglandin (PG) F2α. PGF2α causes dysrhythmic uterine contractions and consequently abdominal pain and uterine ischemia (which leads to endometrial sloughing). The accompanying symptoms of primary dysmenorrhea (e.g., headache, diarrhea, fatigue, nausea) are also believed to be mediated by PGF2α. NSAIDs such as ibuprofen are the first-line treatment for primary dysmenorrhea since they inhibit PG synthesis. Patients that do not respond to NSAIDs should be treated with oral contraceptive pills, which decrease PG levels by suppressing ovulation.

B) INCORRECT:

Endometriotic cell implants in the ovaries, fallopian tubes, or cervix are found in patients with endometriosis, which can cause secondary dysmenorrhea. However, patients with secondary dysmenorrhea due to endometriosis typically present with rectovaginal tenderness, adnexal masses, dyspareunia, and pre- or post-menstrual bleeding. Moreover, patients with endometriosis usually become symptomatic after adolescence (20–40 years).
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of appendix specimen (H&E stain; low magnification)

The appendix mucosa shows crypts (arrows), and the adjoining lamina propria contains lymph follicles (L). There is an internal circular muscular layer (Mc) and an external longitudinal muscular layer (Ml), which is typical for the GI tract.

The subserous connective and fat tissue of the mesoappendix and the external longitudinal muscular layer contain ectopic endometrial glands (green overlay) that are surrounded by a dark (basophilic) stroma, which is consistent with the diagnosis of endometriosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Activation of lymphatic cells in the intestinal walls and local tissue damage can be found in patients with inflammatory bowel disease. Often, patients with IBD become symptomatic during adolescence and present with abdominal pain as well as diarrhea and weight loss. The pain is usually constant and associated with defecation. A cyclical pain that occurs only two days before the patient's menses instead indicates primary dysmenorrhea.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of colonic mucosal tissue (H&E stain; 450x magnification)

Colonic crypts (example indicated by green dashed outline) with goblet cells (examples indicated by yellow overlays) and an epithelioid cell granuloma without necrosis (red overlay) are visible. In the area immediately surrounding the granuloma and its multinucleated giant cell (purple overlay), a lymphocytic infiltrate (white arrowhead) and numerous neutrophil granulocytes can be found.

These findings are characteristic of Crohn disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Ascending infection of the uterus, fallopian tubes, ovaries, or surrounding tissue is the cause of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). Although this patient's sexual history puts her at risk of PID, patients would typically present with progressive lower abdominal or pelvic pain, cervical motion or adnexal tenderness, fever, nausea, dyspareunia, and vaginal discharge. Episodic pelvic pain that lasts only a few days and is associated with menstruation is not typical for PID and rather indicates primary dysmenorrhea.
Image Description:

Purulent discharge can be seen on this patient's vulva on external genital examination.

E) INCORRECT:

A fluid-filled sac within the ovary would be present in patients with an ovarian cyst. While complications of ovarian cysts (e.g., ruptured ovarian cyst) can also cause pelvic pain, the pain would usually be severe, with a sudden onset, rather than episodic and associated with menses. Uncomplicated cysts are usually asymptomatic and an incidental finding on ultrasound.

F) INCORRECT:

Pregnancy should always be considered in sexually active women and adolescents of childbearing age such as this girl. However, the episodic pelvic pain and a regular 28-day menstrual cycle make pregnancy an unlikely cause of this girl's symptoms. Regardless, because of this girl's history of inconsistent use of contraception, a pregnancy test should be performed and the patient should be educated about safer sex practices.

G) INCORRECT:

Endometrial tissue within the uterine wall is found in patients with adenomyosis, which can cause secondary dysmenorrhea and manifest with episodic pain associated with menses. However, adenomyosis is more common in women between 40–50 years of age and is typically associated with menorrhagia. Also, a pelvic exam often shows an enlarged, boggy, symmetric uterus.

H) INCORRECT:

Urinary tract infections are typically caused by ascending bacterial infections from the urethra. Females and sexually active individuals, such as this patient, are more commonly affected, and abdominal or back pain is a common feature of UTIs. However, the pain is usually progressive rather than episodic and other features of UTIs such as dysuria, urinary frequency, urinary urgency, and suprapubic tenderness are absent in this patient.

I) INCORRECT:

Uterine leiomyomas (fibroids) are hormone-sensitive smooth muscle tumors of the myometrium and a common cause of secondary dysmenorrhea. Leiomyomas typically occur in women between 25–45 years and, unlike in this patient, heavy menstrual bleeding, menorrhagia, and metrorrhagia are common. Additionally, a pelvic exam shows an enlarged, firm, and irregular uterus.
questions.hint: Episodic lower abdominal pain shortly before menstruation in an adolescent with a normal physical exam suggests primary dysmenorrhea.

questions.text:
A 36-year-old woman comes to the physician because she has not had her menstrual period for the past 6 months. During this time, she has had frequent headaches, difficulty sleeping, and increased sweating. She has not had any weight changes. Over the past year, menses occurred at irregular 30- to 45-day intervals with light flow. The patient underwent two successful cesarean deliveries at the ages of 28 and 32 years. She has two healthy children. She is sexually active with her husband and they do not use contraception. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Estradiol

8 pg/mL (mid-follicular phase: N = 27–123)



Follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH)
200 mIU/mL



Luteinizing hormone (LH)
180 mIU/mL


Prolactin
16 ng/mL


Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The low T3/T4 levels associated with primary hypothyroidism cause a compensatory increase of thyroid-stimulating hormone and thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH). TRH stimulates prolactin production, which then leads to a suppression of LH and FSH. Therefore, primary hypothyroidism can indeed cause amenorrhea, but it would be associated with low LH and FSH levels. Additionally, other typical features, such as fatigue, weight gain, cold intolerance, dry skin, and hair loss, would be expected.

B) INCORRECT:

Hyperprolactinemia causes amenorrhea and is associated with signs of mass effect (headache). However, it would also manifest with other symptoms such as galactorrhea, signs of hypogonadism, and possibly bitemporal hemianopsia. Moreover, patients with hyperprolactinemia normally present with high prolactin levels and low FSH and LH levels.

C) INCORRECT:

Pregnancy should be suspected in any woman of reproductive age who presents with amenorrhea and is otherwise healthy. However, pregnancy would be associated with low FSH and LH levels, as well as high prolactin levels. Moreover, in pregnancy, a suprapubic mass (the gravid uterus) would be palpable by the 4th month of amenorrhea.

D) CORRECT:

Primary ovarian insufficiency (POI), also known as premature ovarian failure, is inadequate ovarian function in women below the age of 40 years. Patients with POI typically present with hypergonadotropic hypogonadism (high FSH and LH levels, low estrogen levels) and climacteric features (headache, impaired sleep, increased sweating) followed by amenorrhea. POI also explains why this patient has not conceived again despite not using contraception. Treatment of POI includes hormone replacement therapy.

E) INCORRECT:

Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) can manifest with amenorrhea and mood changes. However, other typical features of PCOS, such as hirsutism, acne, and weight gain are not seen in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

Major depressive disorder (MDD) can be associated with headaches, sleep disturbance, and potentially cause menstrual irregularity. However, other features of MDD such as depressed mood, anhedonia, and difficulty concentrating would also be expected. Moreover, MDD does not explain the hormone levels seen in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient presents with secondary amenorrhea, very low estrogen levels, and elevated FSH and LH levels.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of vaginal bleeding for 2–5 days every 2–3 weeks. The flow is heavy with the passage of clots requiring a thick pad every 2–3 hours. Menarche occurred at 10 years of age, and menses previously occurred at regular 28- to 32-day intervals and lasted for 5 days with normal flow. Her only medication is a multivitamin. She has no children. Her mother was diagnosed with ovarian cancer at 60 years of age. She is 158 cm (5 ft 2 in) tall and weighs 86 kg (190 lb); BMI is 34 kg/m2. Her temperature is 36.6°C (97.8°F), pulse is 86/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows a normal-sized uterus. Laboratory studies, including a complete blood count, thyroid function tests, and coagulation studies are within the reference ranges. A urine pregnancy test is negative. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Endometrial ablation is the surgical removal of the lining of the uterus and is used to treat benign causes of AUB (e.g., fibroids). Fibroids typically manifest with heavy, regular bleeding rather than the irregular bleeding seen here. While endometrial ablation would reduce this patient's bleeding, it would not be appropriate for the diagnosis or treatment of endometrial hyperplasia, which is the likely cause of this patient's symptoms.

B) CORRECT:

Endometrial sampling is indicated in the diagnostic workup of patients < 45 years of age with any of the following: persistent bleeding despite pharmacological treatment, unopposed estrogen (e.g., due to obesity or polycystic ovary syndrome), or other risk factors for endometrial hyperplasia or neoplasia (e.g., type 2 diabetes, nulliparity, early menarche, obesity). Endometrial sampling is also indicated in patients ≥ 45 years of age with any uterine bleeding and postmenopausal patients with an endometrial thickness > 4 mm. This patient is < 45 years of age and has several risk factors for endometrial cancer (nulliparity, early menarche, obesity). Therefore, the most appropriate next step in management is an endometrial biopsy.

A pelvic ultrasound should be considered in patients with AUB to rule out structural abnormalities (e.g., leiomyomas) and evaluate endometrial thickness. However, because endometrial thickness significantly varies during the menstrual cycle in reproductive-age individuals, pelvic ultrasound is not required before performing an endometrial biopsy.

C) INCORRECT:

Ultrasound may be used in the workup of AUB. However, transvaginal rather than abdominal ultrasound is indicated to rule out structural anomalies and evaluate endometrial thickness. Moreover, a more sensitive diagnostic test is often used first-line in premenopausal patients < 45 years of age with persistent bleeding and risk factors for endometrial cancer (e.g., obesity, nulliparity, early menarche), as seen here.

D) INCORRECT:

Combined oral contraceptives (COCPs) are commonly used to treat AUB in premenopausal patients, as COCPs typically reduce dysmenorrhea and make bleeding lighter and more regular. While this patient has AUB, she also has several risk factors for endometrial cancer (e.g., obesity, nulliparity, early menarche), which warrants further investigation, and, therefore, another step should be performed before the initiation of medical management.

E) INCORRECT:

Cyclic progestin therapy can be used to control heavy menstrual bleeding in premenopausal patients with AUB. However, this patient has several risk factors for endometrial cancer (e.g., obesity, nulliparity, early menarche) that warrant further investigation. Therefore, an additional diagnostic step should be completed before initiating management.
questions.hint: Obesity is associated with unopposed estrogen stimulation. This unopposed stimulation is a risk factor for endometrial hyperplasia, which can manifest with abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB). Patients with AUB with a normal initial laboratory workup and a negative pregnancy test should be evaluated based on their bleeding pattern and risk factors for endometrial cancer.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman comes to her primary care physician because she has not had a menstrual period for 6 months. She is a competitive runner and has been training heavily for the past year in preparation for upcoming races. She has no family or personal history of serious illness. She has not been sexually active for the past 9 months. Her temperature is 36.9°C (98.4° F), pulse is 51/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 106/67 mm Hg. Her BMI is 18 kg/m2. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her amenorrhea?

choices.text: Poor synthetic response of ovarian cells to circulating LH and FSH
Decreased frequency of GnRH release from the hypothalamus
Increased LH release and increased ovarian androgen production

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Autoimmune destruction of thyroid cells is seen in patients with Hashimoto thyroiditis. Although hypothyroidism is also a potential cause of amenorrhea that should certainly be considered, this patient has no other symptoms that would suggest this underlying condition (e.g., weight gain, fatigue, cold intolerance). Although hypothyroidism is not the most likely cause of this patient's amenorrhea, TSH levels should be measured in all women with secondary amenorrhea to rule out this condition.

B) INCORRECT:

Poor synthetic response of ovarian cells to circulating LH and FSH is seen in patients with primary ovarian insufficiency. While patients with this condition will ultimately also develop secondary amenorrhea, they initially have intermittent ovulatory cycles and therefore irregular menstrual periods. In addition, patients often present with typical symptoms of estrogen deficiency such as hot flashes and vaginal dryness. Furthermore, the condition more frequently occurs after the age of 30.

C) INCORRECT:

Increased prolactin secretion is found in patients with a pituitary prolactinoma. The condition can also cause secondary amenorrhea, which is also seen in this patient, sometimes in conjunction with galactorrhea. However, this patient's history of excessive exercise and her low BMI make a different cause more likely. Although a prolactinoma is not the most likely cause of this patient's amenorrhea, prolactin levels should be measured in all women with secondary amenorrhea to rule out hyperprolactinemia.

D) CORRECT:

Functional hypothalamic amenorrhea (FHA) is a common cause of amenorrhea in underweight women of reproductive age. FHA can be caused by a variety of factors, such as excessive exercise, reduced caloric intake, or emotional stress. In response to the decreased energy availability in these states, the body regulates the reproductive potential down by decreasing the frequency of GnRH release from the hypothalamus, which subsequently leads to decreased secretion of gonadotropins (FSH and LH), anovulation, and secondary amenorrhea.

E) INCORRECT:

Intrauterine adhesions are the cause of Asherman syndrome. The adhesions prevent the normal cycle of endometrial growth and shedding and can block the uterus, causing secondary amenorrhea. However, the condition is typically caused by uterine instrumentation (e.g., dilation and curettage), postpartum hemorrhage, or uterine infections, of which there is no history in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

Increased LH release and increased ovarian androgen production is seen in patients with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). Although PCOS is the most common reproductive disorder in women and can also cause amenorrhea, patients are obese rather than underweight and often have acne or hirsutism.
questions.hint: Competitive female athletes often present with amenorrhea, which forms part of the “female athlete triad.”

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman comes to the physician because of headaches and difficulty sleeping for the past 2 days. She states that she has had similar symptoms over the past year and that they occur every month around the same time. The episodes are frequently accompanied by decreased concentration, angry feelings, and cravings for sweet foods. She says that during these episodes she is unable to work efficiently and often has arguments with her colleagues and friends. Menses occur at regular 26-day intervals and last for 5 days. Her last menstrual period started about 3 weeks ago. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 8 years. She takes no medications. She appears irritable. Her vital signs are within normal limits. The patient is oriented to person, place, and time. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) is indicated in both PMS and PMDD to alleviate affective symptoms. However, CBT alone has not been shown to completely resolve moderate or severe symptoms associated with these conditions and is therefore insufficient as a monotherapy. CBT can be used as an adjunct therapy in patients who do not benefit from pharmacological treatment.

B) INCORRECT:

A copper intrauterine device (IUD) is an effective birth control method that can be offered to patients who prefer hormone-free contraception. However, this patient requires management for more than birth control. This patient meets the criteria for PMDD and requires different management.

C) INCORRECT:

Bilateral oophorectomy effectively ends symptoms of PMS permanently. However, it is only indicated for women who do not wish to have children and have severe PMS that does not respond to any medical or supportive treatment. Moreover, considering the age of this patient, ovarian preservation is recommended.

D) INCORRECT:

Nicotine has been shown to be an individual triggering factor for PMS symptoms, and its avoidance may therefore be helpful. However, nicotine cessation is not the first-line therapy for PMDD and would likely not provide sufficient relief for this patient's severe symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

Naproxen is indicated to alleviate symptoms associated with PMS (e.g., headaches, breast tenderness, abdominal cramps). While this patient may benefit from NSAIDs for her headaches, she requires a different treatment to manage her PMDD symptoms.

F) CORRECT:

Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs; e.g., sertraline) are recommended by the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists as first-line therapy for PMDD because they have been shown to alleviate physical and affective symptoms with minimal side effects. This patient has recurrent premenstrual episodes with severe symptoms and behavioral changes that cause a clinically significant disturbance in daily life. Therefore, treatment with SSRIs is indicated. This patient should also be advised to quit smoking, which is a known trigger for PMS. Additionally, NSAIDs can be recommended to alleviate her headaches.

Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) are an alternative first-line therapy for patients who desire contraception. OCPs suppress ovulation, thereby reducing somatic and affective symptoms.
questions.hint: This patient's recurrent episodes of headaches, sleep disturbance, difficulty concentrating, and marked anger with increased interpersonal conflicts occur every month in the week before the onset of menses. Her symptoms are consistent with premenstrual dysphoric disorder (PMDD), a severe form of premenstrual syndrome (PMS).

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, aborta 1, comes to the physician for evaluation of irregular menstrual periods. Menarche was at the age of 12 years. Her menses have always occurred at variable intervals, and she has spotting between her periods. Her last menstrual period was 7 months ago. Her one previous pregnancy resulted in a spontaneous, incomplete abortion at 12 weeks'  gestation that was managed with dilation and curettage. Medical history otherwise is unremarkable and she takes no routine medications. She drinks 3 alcoholic drinks on weekends and does not smoke. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 85 kg (187 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 82/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 118/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Prolactin, FSH, and TSH levels are within normal limits. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral contraceptive therapy can be used to replace estrogen and provide contraception in patients with premature ovarian failure (POF), which manifests with secondary amenorrhea. However, this patient's normal levels of FSH exclude POF.

Oral contraceptive therapy can also be used in the management of menstrual abnormalities in patients with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), which can manifest with secondary amenorrhea. However, treatment can only be initiated once PCOS is diagnosed based on the presence of at least two of the Rotterdam criteria. This patient does not have symptoms of hyperandrogenism (e.g., acne, hirsutism) and she would require further evaluation of the ovaries on pelvic ultrasound for the diagnosis of PCOS.

B) CORRECT:

Progesterone withdrawal test is recommended for patients with secondary amenorrhea who are not pregnant and have normal levels of hypothalamic-pituitary hormones (i.e., prolactin, FSH, and TSH). Progesterone is administered for 10 days, after which the patient is observed for withdrawal bleeding. Progesterone withdrawal bleeding confirms that the patient has normal estrogen levels (which leads to the proliferation of the endometrium) and that anovulation is the cause of secondary amenorrhea (anovulation leads to absent corpus luteum, which would otherwise produce progesterone). The absence of withdrawal bleeding suggests hypoestrogenism (due to hypogonadotropic hypogonadism or primary ovarian failure) or uterine obstruction. In such cases, a combined estrogen and progesterone challenge should be performed. Following this combined test, withdrawal bleeding suggests hypoestrogenism, and the absence of bleeding suggests the presence of uterine outflow obstruction (e.g., due to Asherman syndrome). In the latter, a hysteroscopy or hysterosalpingogram should be performed to confirm the diagnosis.
Image Description:

The menstrual cycle consists of two phases: the follicular and the luteal phase. The onset of menses marks the beginning of the follicular phase, which usually lasts 12–14 days but may be variable. The luteal phase begins on the day of ovulation and lasts 14 days.

During the follicular phase, FSH and LH stimulate the development of several follicles, one of which develops as the dominant follicle into the Graafian follicle. An LH surge initiates ovulation. As the oocyte reaches the fallopian tube, the ruptured follicle transforms into the corpus luteum, which produces progesterone. If no pregnancy occurs, the corpus luteum regresses and the progesterone level drops. This drop induces vasospasms in the uterine spiral arteries, ischemia, and sloughing off of the functional endometrial layer, which leads to menstrual bleeding (menstrual phase). During the proliferative phase, the endometrium is built up again in preparation for oocyte implantation during the secretory phase.

1: stages of follicle development; 2: hormone levels; 3: phases of the endometrial cycle; 4: development of the endometrium during the cycle

C) INCORRECT:

Hysteroscopy can be performed in women who are at risk for intrauterine adhesions (e.g., due to history of uterine instrumentation), which can manifest with secondary amenorrhea and normal hypothalamic-pituitary hormones. Intrauterine adhesions can disrupt normal endometrial growth and result in uterine outflow obstruction, with consequent amenorrhea. However, a different diagnostic test should be performed before considering hysteroscopy.

D) INCORRECT:

Gonadotropin therapy is used to treat patients with impaired fertility due to anovulation (e.g., as a result of polycystic ovarian syndrome or premature ovarian failure). Although anovulation can not yet be excluded as the cause of this patient's amenorrhea, she has not reported a history of infertility or a wish to conceive in the future. Moreover, before initiating any treatment, additional workup is required to confirm the cause of this patient's amenorrhea.

E) INCORRECT:

A dexamethasone suppression test is used to diagnose Cushing syndrome, which can manifest with amenorrhea, obesity, and normal hypothalamic-pituitary hormones. However, the absence of other clinical features such as hypertension, abdominal striae, abnormal cutaneous fat deposit, hirsutism, and/or emotional lability makes this diagnosis unlikely.

F) INCORRECT:

MRI of the brain is indicated for patients with secondary amenorrhea and concurrent hyperprolactinemia to assess for the presence of a prolactinoma. This patient, however, has normal prolactin levels. A different step is more appropriate at this time.
questions.hint: The absence of menses for more than 6 months in a woman with previously irregular menstrual cycles is consistent with secondary amenorrhea. This patient's normal prolactin, TSH, and FSH concentrations and negative pregnancy test rule out prolactinoma, hypothyroidism, ovarian insufficiency, and pregnancy as underlying causes of amenorrhea.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1, comes to the physician because of difficulty conceiving for one year. She is sexually active with her husband 4–5 times a week. The pregnancy and delivery of her first child 3 years ago were uncomplicated. She returned to work as an event coordinator 12 months ago and has found the transition stressful. Menses previously occurred at 30-day intervals and lasted for 3–4 days with moderate flow. Her last menstrual period was three months ago. She has occasional vaginal dryness. The patient runs 5 to 10 miles every day. Her BMI is 19 kg/m2. Her pulse is 73/min and blood pressure is 125/70 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows no abnormalities. Pelvic examination shows dry vaginal mucosa. A serum pregnancy test is negative. Serum studies show:


Prolactin
18 μg/L


Thyroid-stimulating hormone
2.5 mU/L


Follicle-stimulating hormone
3.6 U/L


Luteinizing hormone
2.3 U/L


Ultrasound of the pelvis shows no abnormalities. In addition to dietary and exercise counseling, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Offer combined estrogen and progestin therapy
Reassess serum beta human chorionic gonadotropin in one week
Obtain MRI of the pituitary gland

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Clomiphene citrate is primarily used to treat women with oligoovulation or anovulation due to polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). Clomiphene citrate stimulates ovulation by inhibiting the negative feedback of endogenous estrogen on the hypothalamus, thereby increasing the secretion of FSH and LH. This patient does not have any features of PCOS (e.g., hirsutism, ovarian cysts). Her secondary amenorrhea, infertility, vaginal dryness, and low levels of FSH and LH are suggestive of FHA, for which clomiphene is only recommended if first-line therapy is unsuccessful.

B) INCORRECT:

In vitro fertilization can be considered for the treatment of infertility if other, less invasive methods are not successful. This woman has evidence of FHA and appropriate first-line treatment should first be attempted.

C) INCORRECT:

Estrogen and progestin can be used to induce menses in patients with anovulation. Very high levels of estrogen trigger a positive feedback loop, resulting in the release of LH from the pituitary gland, which induces ovulation. Progestin stimulates endometrial proliferation, and an abrupt decline in concentration induces menses. While this therapy could potentially restore her menses, it does not address the underlying etiology of her infertility and is not recommended for the management of FHA. Additionally, it is a form of birth control and should not be given to women who are attempting pregnancy.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's history of stress and excessive exercise in conjunction with a low to normal BMI is consistent with FHA, a cause of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. FHA is due to a dysfunction in the pulsatile secretion of GnRH. In patients with FHA, the most important aspect of treatment is reaching normal levels of energy balance. This patient should, therefore, be counseled on making both dietary and exercise changes to increase her BMI and/or fat mass. The underlying cause (e.g., stress) of FHA should also be addressed. In women who are planning pregnancy and have a BMI over 18.5 kg/m2, pulsatile GnRH injections can be administered to increase FSH and LH levels and thereby stimulate ovulation.

E) INCORRECT:

Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) can be used to stimulate spermatogenesis and testicular growth in postpubertal men who present with hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. It is not recommended in the treatment of women with FHA.

F) INCORRECT:

The serum beta-hCG test is a quantitative pregnancy test with high sensitivity that can detect pregnancy ∼ 6–9 days after fertilization. While it is always important to rule out pregnancy when evaluating amenorrhea, this patient has already had a negative pregnancy test. Her history and laboratory studies suggest anovulation secondary to FHA as the etiology of her infertility.

G) INCORRECT:

MRI is recommended in patients with unexplained hypogonadotropic hypogonadism or symptoms of pituitary dysfunction to rule out pituitary gland tumors such as prolactinoma, which may manifest with amenorrhea. However, patients with prolactinoma typically have other characteristic features (e.g., headache, visual field defects, diplopia). Moreover, a normal prolactin level makes prolactinoma unlikely.
questions.hint: This patient's history and low levels of FSH and LH suggest functional hypothalamic amenorrhea (FHA), most likely due to stress and excessive exercise.

questions.text:
A 15-year-old girl comes to the physician because she has not had menstrual bleeding for the past 3 months. Menses had previously occurred at irregular 15–45 day intervals with moderate to heavy flow. Menarche was at the age of 14 years. She started having sexual intercourse with her boyfriend about 3 months ago. Six months ago she had a manic episode, which was treated with risperidone. Her mother has PCOS and her father has type 2 diabetes mellitus. She is very conscious of her weight and appearance. She is 171 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 79 kg (174 lb); BMI is 27 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 60/min, and blood pressure is 116/70 mm Hg. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Pelvic examination shows a normal vagina and cervix. Serum hormone studies show:


Prolactin
16 ng/mL


Thyroid-stimulating hormone
3.8 μU/mL


Follicle-stimulating hormone
6 mIU/mL


Luteinizing hormone
5.1 mIU/mL


Progesterone

0.8 ng/mL (follicular N < 3; luteal N > 3–5)


Testosterone
28 ng/dL (N = 5–40)


A urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her symptoms?

choices.text: Congenital defect of the Mullerian ducts

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fibroids most commonly occur in women aged 25–45 years and can cause menstrual abnormalities, including hypermenorrhea, menorrhagia, and dysmenorrhea, but progesterone levels would be normal. Large leiomyomas can cause back or pelvic pain and discomfort, as well as urinary tract or bowel symptoms (e.g., urinary frequency/retention, constipation). This patient's symptoms are not consistent with a presentation of fibroids.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with Mullerian duct agenesis are asymptomatic until puberty when they present with primary amenorrhea. The ovaries and hypothalamic axis are not affected in this condition. This patient has secondary amenorrhea and the pelvic exam shows no abnormalities, making this diagnosis unlikely. Furthermore, low progesterone levels would not be expected.

C) INCORRECT:

Bulimia nervosa, which primarily affects adolescent girls and young women, can cause hypogonadotropic hypogonadism with secondary amenorrhea. In bulimia nervosa, BMI is typically > 18.5. Although this patient is conscious of her weight, she does not have a history of binge eating or periods of starvation, nor symptoms of purging (e.g., swollen parotid glands, poor dental status). In addition, levels of FSH and LH would be reduced in bulimia nervosa.

D) INCORRECT:

Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) is typically seen in overweight patients and is a common cause of menstrual irregularities, including secondary amenorrhea and oligomenorrhea. Maternal PCOS is a confirmed risk factor and onset is typically during adolescence. However, PCOS also manifests with signs of hyperandrogenism such as hirsutism and acne, which are not seen in this patient. Moreover, levels of FSH, LH, and testosterone would be elevated and pelvic exam and/or ultrasound would show enlarged ovaries. Therefore, PCOS is unlikely.

E) CORRECT:

Oligomenorrhea combined with progesterone levels consistent with the follicular phase of the menstrual cycle is highly suggestive of anovulation. During the anovulatory cycles, there is no luteal phase because ovulation does not occur and the endometrium remains in the follicular phase. Anovulation is a common physiological finding in adolescent girls for up to a few years after menarche and is caused by immaturity of the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis. Patients should be reassured that their menstrual cycle will become regular with age and no further treatment is required. Other causes of anovulation include polycystic ovarian syndrome, hyperprolactinemia, premature ovarian failure, hyperthyroidism, obesity, anorexia, and stress.

F) INCORRECT:

Risperidone can cause hyperprolactinemia, which suppresses the hypothalamic secretion of GnRH, resulting in hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. Irregular menstrual cycles, galactorrhea, and obesity can occur secondary to risperidone intake. FSH and LH levels would be reduced and serum prolactin levels would be elevated.

G) INCORRECT:

Primary ovarian insufficiency may manifest with symptoms very similar to the ones in this patient with menstrual irregularities and oligomenorrhea. Common causes of this condition in adolescence are chromosomal abnormalities (e.g., Turner syndrome). However, FSH levels are typically very high, which is not the case in this patient.
questions.hint: Oligomenorrhea, which is preceded by irregular menstrual cycles and menorrhagia, is a common occurrence in adolescents that can persist up to a few years after menarche.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of pain during intercourse and vaginal dryness. The patient has also had intermittent hot flashes and fatigue during this time. Over the past year, her periods have become irregular. Her last menstrual period was over 6 months ago. She is sexually active with one partner and does not use protection or contraception. She has a history of acute lymphoblastic leukemia during childhood, which has remained in remission. Pelvic examination shows an atrophic cervix and vagina. A urinary pregnancy test is negative. A progestin challenge test is performed and shows no withdrawal bleeding. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Decreased GnRH levels are seen in hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, which can be congenital (e.g., Kallmann syndrome) or acquired (e.g., excessive exercise, reduced caloric intake, stress, pituitary lesions). While acquired cases of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism cause secondary amenorrhea, the absence of a history of excessive exercise or eating disorders and the presence of vaginal dryness and hot flashes (which are atypical for these conditions) make hypogonadotropic hypogonadism unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Decreased luteinizing hormone (LH) levels are seen in hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, which can be congenital (e.g., Kallmann syndrome) or acquired (e.g., excessive exercise, reduced caloric intake, stress, pituitary lesions). While cases of acquired hypogonadotropic hypogonadism cause secondary amenorrhea, the absence of a history of excessive exercise or eating disorders and the presence of vaginal dryness and hot flashes (which are atypical for these conditions) make hypogonadotropic hypogonadism unlikely. Furthermore, this patient's presentation is highly suggestive of primary ovarian insufficiency, in which the loss of feedback inhibition of estrogen on gonadotropin (e.g., FSH, LH) secretion results in elevated serum levels of these hormones.

C) INCORRECT:

Decreased estrogen levels in ovarian failure result in increased follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) levels due to the loss of feedback inhibition of estrogen on gonadotropin secretion. As a result, the ratio of FSH to estrogen would be high in a patient with suspected primary ovarian failure.

D) CORRECT:

Primary ovarian insufficiency manifests with decreased estrogen levels as well as elevated FSH levels due to loss of feedback inhibition from estrogen on gonadotropin secretion from the anterior pituitary.

While most cases of POI are idiopathic, known causes include treatment with radiation and/or chemotherapy (this patient has a history of acute lymphoblastic leukemia during childhood) and certain genetic disorders (e.g., Turner syndrome, fragile X syndrome).

E) INCORRECT:
