Testosterone levels and other androgens are usually increased in cases of polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS), which can also manifest with secondary amenorrhea. However, this patient lacks other typical manifestations of PCOS, such as hirsutism, acne vulgaris, obesity, or metabolic syndrome. Hot flashes and vaginal dryness are not typically seen in PCOS.

F) INCORRECT:

Increased TSH is seen in primary hypothyroidism, which can also manifest with secondary amenorrhea and fatigue. However, this patient lacks other typical features of hypothyroidism, such as weight gain, cold intolerance, dry skin, constipation.
questions.hint: This patient presents with secondary amenorrhea and features of low estrogen levels (hot flashes, vaginal dryness) before the age of 40, which should raise concern for primary ovarian insufficiency.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl comes to the physician because of a 2-year history of irregular menstrual bleeding. Menses have occurred at irregular 45- to 60-day intervals since menarche at the age of 13 years. Her last menstrual period was 5 weeks ago and lasted for 7 days with heavy flow and no cramping. She is not sexually active. She is 171 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 58 kg (128 lb); BMI is 20 kg/m2. Her temperature is 36.6°C (97.8°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows a normal-appearing vagina and cervix. Bimanual examination shows a normal-sized uterus and no palpable adnexal masses. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with nonsecreting pituitary adenomas may present with oligomenorrhea. Nonsecreting pituitary macroadenomas can exert a mass effect on the remaining gland or the hypothalamus, resulting in oligomenorrhea due to deficient FSH and LH. However, additional signs, including headache, visual deficits, and symptoms associated with other hormone deficiencies (e.g., hypothyroidism) would also be expected. Patients with functioning (i.e., hormone-producing) adenomas (e.g., prolactinomas) present with galactorrhea, which is absent in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Endometriosis affects up to 10% of women and manifests with a variety of menstrual abnormalities. However, rather than oligomenorrhea, patients more commonly present with dysmenorrhea, premenstrual or postmenstrual bleeding. The most common symptom is chronic pelvic pain that occurs shortly before the menstrual cycle begins. Rectovaginal tenderness and adnexal masses on physical examination would also be expected.

C) INCORRECT:

Polycystic ovary syndrome is characterized by hyperandrogenism, oligoovulation or anovulation, and polycystic ovaries. Patients often present with menstrual irregularities (e.g., primary amenorrhea, oligomenorrhea, secondary amenorrhea) during adolescence. Moreover, signs of obesity, metabolic syndrome, and virilization (e.g., excess hair growth, acne) due to hyperandrogenism would be present. This patient's oligomenorrhea likely results from another underlying cause.

D) CORRECT:

Anovulatory cycles are the most common cause of abnormal uterine bleeding in otherwise healthy adolescents and typically occur up to 2 years after menarche due to an immature hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis. Anovulation leads to a deficit in progesterone production, while unopposed estrogen continues to cause abnormal growth of the endometrial lining and vessels. If increasing estrogen levels trigger negative feedback in the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis, a drop in FSH/LH and estrogen levels leads to a sudden loss of endometrium that can cause heavy and prolonged bleeding. Patients should be reassured that this phenomenon is not pathological by nature and that no further workup is required.

If oligomenorrhea is prolonged (> 2 years), further evaluation is warranted to rule out pathological causes.

E) INCORRECT:

Ovarian insufficiency is characterized by less frequent (or even absent) menstrual cycles and hypoestrogenism in women < 40 years of age. However, patients with ovarian insufficiency typically present with perimenopausal, autonomic symptoms (e.g., hot flashes, heat intolerance), and atrophic features (e.g., breast tenderness, vaginal dryness).
questions.hint: Oligomenorrhea in the first 2 years after menarche is a common finding in otherwise healthy teenagers.

questions.text: A healthy 31-year-old woman comes to the physician because she is trying to conceive. She is interested in tracking her hormonal cycle in order to determine her fertility period. An increase in the levels of which of the following is the best indicator that ovulation has already occurred?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ovulation is preceded by an increase in estrogen. After ovulation occurs (luteal phase), estrogen levels decline.

B) INCORRECT:

Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) is essential for the development and maturation of ovarian follicles and the stimulation of ovulation. GnRH is secreted in a pulsatile manner and is regulated by estrogen and androgens, which influence the amount and frequency of GnRH pulses. Its plasma peaks do not coincide with ovulation, which means it is not an appropriate indicator of when ovulation has occurred.

C) INCORRECT:

During the follicular phase of the menstrual cycle, follicle stimulating hormone (FSH) stimulates the development of several ovarian follicles in the ovaries. FSH levels increase during days 1–7 of the menstrual cycle, approximately 1 week prior to ovulation. The hormone is not directly involved in ovulation and therefore is not an appropriate indicator of when ovulation has already occurred.

D) CORRECT:

Towards the end of the follicular phase of the menstrual cycle, a peak in estrogen levels triggers an LH surge, which induces ovulation. After ovulation, the ruptured follicle transforms into the corpus luteum which produces progesterone. An increase in progesterone levels is therefore an indicator that ovulation has occurred. Progesterone maintains the endometrium and inhibits the secretion of gonadotropins (FSH and LH) throughout the luteal phase of the menstrual cycle. If fertilization and implantation occur, the production of β-hCG maintains the corpus luteum and thus progesterone for the first weeks of pregnancy.

Most ovulation kits measure the LH surge, which indicates ovulation will occur in the next 24–36 hours.
Image Description:

The menstrual cycle consists of two phases: the follicular and the luteal phase. The onset of menses marks the beginning of the follicular phase, which usually lasts 12–14 days but may be variable. The luteal phase begins on the day of ovulation and lasts 14 days.

During the follicular phase, FSH and LH stimulate the development of several follicles, one of which develops as the dominant follicle into the Graafian follicle. An LH surge initiates ovulation. As the oocyte reaches the fallopian tube, the ruptured follicle transforms into the corpus luteum, which produces progesterone. If no pregnancy occurs, the corpus luteum regresses and the progesterone level drops. This drop induces vasospasms in the uterine spiral arteries, ischemia, and sloughing off of the functional endometrial layer, which leads to menstrual bleeding (menstrual phase). During the proliferative phase, the endometrium is built up again in preparation for oocyte implantation during the secretory phase.

1: stages of follicle development; 2: hormone levels; 3: phases of the endometrial cycle; 4: development of the endometrium during the cycle

E) INCORRECT:

Approximately 24–36 hours prior to ovulation, a peak in luteinizing hormone (LH) occurs, which induces the rupture of the Graafian follicle. Following ovulation, the LH level rapidly decreases. Since the LH peak is very short and occurs prior to ovulation, it is not a reliable indicator that ovulation has already occurred.
questions.hint: The level of this hormone increases right after ovulation. If fertilization and implantation do not occur, the same hormone decreases in concentration, causing the endometrium to be shed.

questions.text: An investigator is studying the menstrual cycle in premenopausal female volunteers with normal ovarian function. Endometrial biopsy specimens are taken from each volunteer every 6 days for a month, and capillary lumen area and endometrial layer thickness are measured. Microscopic examination of one such specimen shows condensed endometrial cells with deeply eosinophilic cytoplasm and basophilic, fragmented, shrunken nuclei. These types of cells are most likely to be seen in which of the following points in the menstrual cycle?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

“A” corresponds to the early follicular phase of the ovarian cycle that begins just after the functional layer of the endometrium has been shed. During this time, estrogen begins to stimulate endometrial proliferation. However, because levels of estrogen and progesterone are relatively low, the new functional layer is underdeveloped. An endometrial biopsy taken at this stage would show thin surface epithelium with short, straight glands and only a few mitotic figures, not apoptotic cells.

B) INCORRECT:

“B” corresponds to the estrogen surge that occurs at the end of the follicular phase of the ovarian cycle. During this time, rising levels of follicle-stimulating hormone stimulate ovarian folliculogenesis. The developing follicles secrete estrogen, which stimulates endometrial cells to proliferate (proliferative phase of the uterine cycle). An endometrial biopsy taken at this stage would show long and tortuous glands, cells with numerous mitotic figures in glandular epithelium, and stromal edema, not apoptotic cells.

C) INCORRECT:

“C” corresponds to the luteinizing hormone surge that occurs at the end of the follicular phase of the ovarian cycle in response to rising levels of estrogen. High estrogen levels stimulate the endometrial cells to proliferate (proliferative phase of the uterine cycle). An endometrial biopsy taken at this stage would show long and tortuous glands, cells with numerous mitotic figures in glandular epithelium, and stromal edema, not apoptotic cells.

D) INCORRECT:

“D” corresponds to the early portions of the secretory phase (of the uterine cycle) and luteal phase (of the ovarian cycle). During this time, the corpus luteum secretes progesterone, which prohibits further endometrial proliferation and promotes endometrial differentiation. The glandular cells of the endometrium secrete glycogen-rich vacuoles that provide nutrition to a blastocyst if implantation occurs. An endometrial biopsy taken at this stage would show subnuclear vacuoles and a few mitotic figures, not apoptotic cells.

E) INCORRECT:

“E” corresponds to the middle of the secretory phase (of the uterine cycle) and luteal phase (of the ovarian cycle). During this period, the functional layer of the endometrium is prepared for implantation. An endometrial biopsy taken at this stage would show progesterone-induced stromal edema and glycogen-rich vacuoles at the cellular apex (which provide nutrition to a blastocyst if implantation occurs), not apoptotic cells.

F) CORRECT:

Apoptotic endometrial cells are most likely to be found around day 28 of the menstrual cycle (“F”), which corresponds to the ends of the secretory phase of the uterine cycle and luteal phase of the ovarian cycle. If pregnancy has not occurred, the corpus luteum degenerates, which decreases progesterone and estrogen levels. The withdrawal of progesterone induces apoptosis of the endometrial cells and vasospasms in the uterine spiral arteries (which results in ischemic necrosis), subsequently leading to sloughing off of the functional layer of the endometrium (causes menses).
Image Description:

The menstrual cycle consists of two phases: the follicular and the luteal phase. The onset of menses marks the beginning of the follicular phase, which usually lasts 12–14 days but may be variable. The luteal phase begins on the day of ovulation and lasts 14 days.

During the follicular phase, FSH and LH stimulate the development of several follicles, one of which develops as the dominant follicle into the Graafian follicle. An LH surge initiates ovulation. As the oocyte reaches the fallopian tube, the ruptured follicle transforms into the corpus luteum, which produces progesterone. If no pregnancy occurs, the corpus luteum regresses and the progesterone level drops. This drop induces vasospasms in the uterine spiral arteries, ischemia, and sloughing off of the functional endometrial layer, which leads to menstrual bleeding (menstrual phase). During the proliferative phase, the endometrium is built up again in preparation for oocyte implantation during the secretory phase.

1: stages of follicle development; 2: hormone levels; 3: phases of the endometrial cycle; 4: development of the endometrium during the cycle
questions.hint: The biopsy specimen shows nuclear shrinkage (pyknosis) and fragmentation (karyorrhexis), which are features seen in cells undergoing apoptosis. Endometrial cells undergo apoptosis just prior to being sloughed off.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2, comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of heavy, irregular menstrual bleeding. Pelvic examination shows blood and clots in the posterior fornix and normal-appearing internal and external genitalia. An endometrial biopsy specimen shows straight uniform tubular glands lined with tall pseudostratified columnar epithelial cells with high mitotic activity embedded in an edematous stroma. Increased activity of which of the following is directly responsible for the histologic appearance of the biopsy specimen?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Luteinizing hormone (LH) increases the activity of the enzyme desmolase, which converts cholesterol to androstenedione (precursor of estrogens) in theca interna cells. A rapid increase in LH levels (LH surge) occurs at the end of the proliferative phase of the menstrual cycle and induces ovulation. Although this patient presents with histological findings consistent with the proliferative phase, increased LH activity is not directly responsible for endometrial proliferation.

B) INCORRECT:

During the secretory phase of the menstrual cycle, the corpus luteum is responsible for secreting progesterone. The effects of progesterone include endometrial differentiation, which is essential for implantation of the blastocyst. Unlike the histological findings seen in this patient, the secretory phase of the menstrual cycle typically presents with coiled (cork-screw shaped) glands filled with glycogen-rich secretions, edematous stromal cells, and increased vascularity.

C) INCORRECT:

5-alpha-reductase converts testosterone into the more active form dihydrotestosterone (DHT). Increased activity of 5-alpha-reductase and elevated levels of DHT would result in symptoms of virilization, such as ambiguous genitalia, hirsutism, frontal balding, and deepening of the voice, none of which are seen in this patient. The activity of 5-alpha-reductase is not elevated during the proliferative phase of the menstrual cycle.

Increased activity of 5-alpha-reductase is seen in women with polycystic ovary syndrome, which can present with irregular menstrual bleeding.

D) INCORRECT:

Theca externa cells form the outer layer of the theca folliculi, which surrounds the ovarian follicles. The theca externa consists of epithelial fibroblast-like cells, which contain abundant collagen and are important for contraction and rupture of mature follicles. Unlike the theca interna, which produce androgens under stimulation of luteinizing hormone, theca externa cells do not produce hormones.

E) CORRECT:

Aromatase is expressed in the granulosa cells of the ovaries. FSH-mediated activation of aromatase leads to conversion of androstenedione to estrone, and testosterone to estradiol. High aromatase activity results in a high estrogenic state, which can cause breast tenderness, endometrial proliferation, irregular menses, and abnormal uterine bleeding. A patient with an endometrial biopsy consistent with the proliferative phase of the menstrual cycle is most likely in a high estrogenic state secondary to increased aromatase activity.
Image Description:

The menstrual cycle consists of two phases: the follicular and the luteal phase. The onset of menses marks the beginning of the follicular phase, which usually lasts 12–14 days but may be variable. The luteal phase begins on the day of ovulation and lasts 14 days.

During the follicular phase, FSH and LH stimulate the development of several follicles, one of which develops as the dominant follicle into the Graafian follicle. An LH surge initiates ovulation. As the oocyte reaches the fallopian tube, the ruptured follicle transforms into the corpus luteum, which produces progesterone. If no pregnancy occurs, the corpus luteum regresses and the progesterone level drops. This drop induces vasospasms in the uterine spiral arteries, ischemia, and sloughing off of the functional endometrial layer, which leads to menstrual bleeding (menstrual phase). During the proliferative phase, the endometrium is built up again in preparation for oocyte implantation during the secretory phase.

1: stages of follicle development; 2: hormone levels; 3: phases of the endometrial cycle; 4: development of the endometrium during the cycle
questions.hint: The patient's endometrial biopsy specimen shows features of the proliferative phase of the menstrual cycle (straight uniform tubular glands, tall pseudostratified columnar epithelial cells, high mitotic activity). Endometrial proliferation during this phase is mediated by a class of hormones also responsible for the development of female secondary sex characteristics.

questions.text:
A 15-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents because she has not had menstrual bleeding for the past 2 months. Menses had previously occurred at irregular 15–45 day intervals with moderate to heavy flow. Menarche was at the age of 14 years. Eight months ago, she was diagnosed with bipolar disorder and treatment with risperidone was begun. Her parents report that she is very conscious of her weight and appearance. She is 168 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 76 kg (168 lb); BMI is 27 kg/m2. Pelvic examination shows a normal vagina and cervix. Serum hormone studies show:


Prolactin
14 ng/mL


Follicle-stimulating hormone
5 mIU/mL


Luteinizing hormone
5.2 mIU/mL


Progesterone

0.9 ng/mL (follicular N < 3; luteal N > 3–5)


Testosterone
2.7 nmol/L (N < 3.5)


A urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Primary ovarian insufficiency can present with the menstrual irregularities and oligomenorrhea seen in this patient. Chromosomal abnormalities (e.g., Turner syndrome) are a common cause of this condition in adolescence. However, FSH levels are typically very high, which is not the case in this patient.

B) CORRECT:

Oligomenorrhea combined with low progesterone levels strongly suggests anovulatory cycles, which are common in adolescent girls during the first few months or year after menarche, and are caused by immaturity of the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis. Low levels of progesterone cause the endometrium to remain in the proliferative phase, which often leads to heavy bleeding during menses as well as irregular menses. Patients should be reassured that menstrual cycles will become more regular and predictable after adolescence and no further treatment is required.

Other causes of anovulation include polycystic ovarian syndrome, hyperprolactinemia, premature ovarian failure, hyperthyroidism, obesity, anorexia, and stress.

C) INCORRECT:

Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) is a common cause of menstrual irregularities, including secondary amenorrhea and oligomenorrhea. This patient is overweight, which is commonly seen in patients with PCOS, but she has no signs of hyperandrogenism such as hirsutism and acne. Furthermore, LH and testosterone would be elevated, which is not the case in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Leiomyomas, or fibroids, most commonly occur in women 25–45 years of age and can cause menstrual abnormalities, including hypermenorrhea, menorrhagia, and dysmenorrhea, but progesterone levels would be normal. Large leiomyomas can cause back or pelvic pain and discomfort, as well as urinary tract or bowel symptoms (e.g., urinary frequency/retention, constipation). This patient's symptoms are not consistent with fibroids.

E) INCORRECT:

Risperidone, which is an atypical antipsychotic, can cause hyperprolactinemia. High levels of prolactin suppress the hypothalamic secretion of GnRH, resulting in hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. Irregular menstrual cycles, galactorrhea, and obesity can occur secondary to risperidone intake. FSH and LH levels would be reduced, and serum prolactin levels would be elevated, which is not the case in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

Bulimia nervosa can cause hypogonadotropic hypogonadism with secondary amenorrhea. It primarily affects young women, and the BMI in individuals with bulimia is typically normal or elevated (≥ 18.5 kg/m2), which is consistent with this patient's presentation. Although this patient is conscious of her weight, she does not have a history of binge eating or periods of starvation, nor symptoms of purging, such as swollen parotid glands and poor dental status, which would raise suspicion for bulimia nervosa. In addition, FSH and LH would likely be reduced.
questions.hint: Oligomenorrhea, which is preceded by irregular menstrual cycles and menorrhagia, is common in adolescents during the first few months to years after menarche.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman with a history of acute lymphoblastic leukemia comes to the physician because she has not had a menstrual period for 12 months. Menarche occurred at the age of 11 years, and menses occurred at regular 28-day intervals until they became irregular 1 year ago. Physical examination shows normal female genitalia and bimanual examination shows a normal-sized uterus. Laboratory studies show markedly elevated FSH levels consistent with premature ovarian failure. Fluorescence in situ hybridization studies show a 46,XY karyotype in the peripheral blood cells. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the male karyotype found on chromosomal analysis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Allogeneic stem cell transplantation is used in post-remission therapy of patients with ALL who have a high risk of relapse. In contrast to autologous stem cell transplantation, which involves the removal, storage, and retransfusion of a patient's own cells, allogenous stem cell transplantation refers to the administration of hematopoietic stem cells from a sibling or unrelated donor. Chromosomal analysis in this female patient shows a male genotype (46,XY karyotype) because she received stem cells from a male donor (e.g., sex-mismatched transplantation). This patient's premature ovarian failure is most likely related to cytotoxic effects of chemotherapy and radiation administered prior to the allogeneic stem cell transplantation.

Other types of grafts include isografts (e.g., from an identical twin) and xenografts (e.g., from a pig).

B) INCORRECT:

Müllerian duct agenesis (Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome) is a rare, congenital defect that manifests with normally functioning gonads, female phenotype, and primary amenorrhea due to a missing or abnormal uterus. In contrast to this patient, premature ovarian failure and male genotype on FISH analysis would not be expected.

C) INCORRECT:

21-hydroxylase deficiency is seen in patients with congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH), a group of autosomal recessive defects in the enzymes responsible for cortisol, aldosterone, and androgen synthesis. In contrast to this patient, 21-hydroxylase deficiency in women most commonly manifests with hypotension, virilization, and precocious puberty. Although menstrual irregularities can occur in CAH, the mechanism differs from premature ovarian failure. It would not explain the male genotype seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Radiation is used as CNS preventive therapy in patients with ALL, and it has been associated with amenorrhea and premature ovarian failure due to cytotoxic effects on oocytes. However, radiotherapy of the CNS would not cause a male genotype on FISH, which is seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Defective androgen receptor function is the underlying cause of androgen insensitivity syndrome, an X-linked recessive mutation of the gene locus encoding the androgen receptor. Patients present with amenorrhea, variable degrees of feminization, and a 46,XY karyotype. However, a blind vaginal pouch, uterine agenesis, and primary amenorrhea (rather than secondary amenorrhea) would also be expected.
questions.hint: This woman with a history of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) has secondary amenorrhea due to premature ovarian failure, most likely related to chemotherapy she received in the past. Physical examination shows a female phenotype, whereas chromosomal analysis shows a male genotype.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of infertility. She has a history of anorexia nervosa and has received dietary and behavioral therapy over the past 6 months with minimal improvement in her symptoms. She is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 49 kg (104 lb); her BMI is 17 kg/m2. Physical examination shows pallor and thin, soft, depigmented hair on the arms and back. After an extensive workup, the physician recommends pulsatile GnRH therapy for infertility treatment. At a follow-up examination one week after initiating therapy, a pelvic ultrasound shows a 24-mm hypoechogenic cavity in the right ovary. The patient subsequently receives a drug that results in the resumption of meiosis and the loss of gap junctions between the cumulus granulosa cells and the oocyte. This patient most likely received which of the following drugs at the follow-up examination?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Leuprolide is a GnRH analog that can be used in infertility treatment to stimulate ovarian follicle maturation. This patient, however, has already received pulsatile GnRH to stimulate follicular maturation. Leuprolide does not induce ovulation.

B) INCORRECT:

Mifepristone is a competitive progesterone antagonist most commonly used in conjunction with a prostaglandin analog for medical termination of pregnancy. At low doses, mifepristone leads to endometrial contraction, which promotes premature detachment of the ovum and results in abortion. It would not be indicated in the treatment of infertility to induce ovulation.

C) CORRECT:

Recombinant human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG), which is structurally similar to LH, is commonly used to induce ovulation. After ovarian follicle maturation is achieved with pulsatile GnRH therapy, as seen on this patient's pelvic ultrasound, recombinant hCG can then be administered to induce ovulation as part of assisted reproductive therapy. Recombinant hCG stimulates LH receptors, mimicking the mid-cycle LH surge to stimulate final oocyte maturation and ovulation.

Endogenous hCG, which is normally produced by the placenta after implantation, is used to detect pregnancy and plays no role in ovulation.

D) INCORRECT:

Ethinyl estradiol inhibits follicular maturation and ovulation by decreasing FSH secretion through negative feedback on the pituitary gland. It would not be used for ovulation induction.

E) INCORRECT:

Synthetic medroxyprogesterone can be used in the treatment of infertility to stimulate endometrial changes necessary for successful implantation. Synthetic progesterone, however, has no effect on follicle maturation or ovulation.
questions.hint: Anorexia nervosa can cause infertility as a result of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. Pulsatile GnRH therapy stimulates endogenous FSH secretion and ovarian follicle maturation. Resumption of meiosis and the loss of gap junctions between the oocyte in the follicle and the cumulus granulosa cells are changes that occur during ovulation.

questions.text: A previously healthy 28-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, comes to her primary care physician because she has not had a menstrual period for 4 months. Previously, menses occurred at regular 28-day intervals. She had a spontaneous abortion 10 months ago. Medical history is also remarkable for an abnormal Pap smear treated with loop electrosurgical excision 2 years ago. She is sexually active with one male partner and uses condoms consistently. She is a competitive triathlon athlete and has been training for an upcoming long-distance triathlon. Vital signs are within normal limits. Her BMI is 18 kg/m2. Physical examination, including pelvic examination, shows no abnormalities. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's amenorrhea?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Primary ovarian insufficiency (POI) can develop in a 28-year-old female patient and manifest with secondary amenorrhea due to follicular depletion. However, POI also manifests with vaginal dryness, night sweats, hot flashes, dyspareunia, and irritability, none of which are seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Intrauterine adhesions can occur following trauma to the endometrium during uterine procedures or prolonged intrauterine inflammation and manifest with secondary amenorrhea and pregnancy loss. While this patient has a history of a loop electrosurgical excision procedure, intrauterine adhesions are most commonly seen in patients after uterine dilation and curettage. Moreover, patients with uterine adhesions typically experience abnormal uterine bleeding and pelvic pain, which is not seen here. In addition, this patient has no history (of features) that would suggest prolonged intrauterine inflammation (e.g., pelvic inflammatory disease, chorioamnionitis, endometritis).

C) INCORRECT:

Tumoral production of prolactin is found in patients with a pituitary prolactinoma, which can cause secondary amenorrhea due to suppression of GnRH. However, prolactinomas also manifest with galactorrhea and mass effect (e.g., bilateral hemianopsia, headaches), none of which are seen here.

D) CORRECT:

Functional hypothalamic amenorrhea (FHA) is typically caused by strenuous physical exercise, reduced caloric intake, and/or excessive stress, which leads to decreased leptin and increased cortisol with a consequent decrease in the pulsatile release of GnRH from the hypothalamus. The decreased pulsatile release of GnRH leads to a decrease in FSH and LH secretion, and therefore, a decrease in the production of estrogen, which inhibits normal ovulation and causes amenorrhea. FHA is a diagnosis of exclusion; other causes of amenorrhea, such as pregnancy, primary ovarian insufficiency, hypothyroidism, and hyperprolactinemia must first be ruled out. Treatment usually consists of lifestyle changes (e.g., stress reduction, improving nutrition, increasing BMI > 19 kg/m2). Patients can also be offered pulsatile GnRH or gonadotropin therapy to induce ovulation.

E) INCORRECT:

Anabolic steroid abuse, which is often seen in professional athletes, can cause secondary amenorrhea due to suppression of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis. However, affected patients typically also present with signs of virilization (e.g., voice deepening, hirsutism, male-pattern hair loss, increased muscle mass, clitoromegaly), none of which are seen here.
questions.hint: Women of reproductive age who are underweight or do not consume enough calories (often competitive athletes) can develop amenorrhea due to hypothalamic hypogonadism.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2, comes to the physician because of an 8-month history of heavy bleeding and severe pelvic cramping during her menstrual period. Menses occur at regular 28-day intervals and last for 5–6 days, during which she needs to use 6–8 pads daily. The pelvic cramps usually begin 2 days before the onset of bleeding. Naproxen provides only mild pain relief, and tranexamic acid therapy did not alleviate her symptoms. She worked as a janitor until 2 weeks ago when she was fired for missing several shifts within 1 week because of her symptoms. She does not want to have any more children and underwent tubal ligation 1 year ago. Both of her children were delivered via uncomplicated vaginal deliveries. She is sexually active in a monogamous relationship with her husband. Her only medication is a daily multivitamin. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 15 years. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 68 kg (150 lb); BMI is 25 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination, including pelvic examination, shows no abnormalities. Results of laboratory studies, including a complete blood count, thyroid function tests, and coagulation studies, are within the reference ranges. Transvaginal ultrasonography shows no abnormalities. Endometrial biopsy specimen shows no sign of malignancy. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Combined oral contraceptive pill (COCP) therapy is a first-line treatment for HMB, especially when symptoms persist despite NSAID use. However, COCPs are contraindicated in patients ≥ 35 years of age who smoke ≥ 15 cigarettes/day due to increased risk of cardiovascular complications.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient's HMB and severe cyclical pain significantly reduce her quality of life, so she requires treatment.

C) CORRECT:

Endometrial ablation is a treatment option for patients with ovulatory HMB and no desire for future pregnancy when medical therapy is unsuccessful or contraindicated. In this patient, NSAIDs only provided minimal pain relief, and treatment with tranexamic acid did not improve her symptoms. Moreover, oral contraceptives are contraindicated because of her smoking history and age. Finally, this patient does not have any contraindications for endometrial ablation, such as pregnancy, active pelvic infection, presence of an intrauterine device, and a history of uterine surgery, or complex or atypical endometrial hyperplasia or cancer.

HMB is a form of abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB). The most common causes of AUB can be classified using the PALM-COEIN system: Polyps, Adenomyosis, Leiomyomas, Malignancy and hyperplasia, Coagulopathy, Ovulatory dysfunction, Endometrial, Iatrogenic, Not otherwise classified. This patient presents with HMB in combination with normal findings on physical examination, laboratory evaluation, ultrasonography, and biopsy, which is consistent with endometrial AUB, a diagnosis of exclusion.

D) INCORRECT:

Hysterectomy is a definitive treatment option for patients with HMB who do not desire future pregnancy. However, hysterectomy is an invasive procedure with a high risk of complications, and it is therefore only indicated in patients who do not respond to any other treatment.

E) INCORRECT:

A copper intrauterine device (IUD) is not indicated for the treatment of HMB and may even worsen symptoms. On the other hand, a progestin IUD (i.e., levonorgestrel-releasing) is an effective, reversible, easy-to-use treatment option for patients with HMB, with the added benefit of long-term contraception. A progestin IUD is a viable alternative treatment option for this patient, but a copper IUD is not.
questions.hint: This patient has chronic heavy menstrual bleeding (HMB) that significantly impairs her quality of life. She underwent a tubal ligation because she does not want any more children.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman (gravida 0, para 0) reports a 2-month history of amenorrhea, beginning when she discontinued her oral contraceptive pill. Her menarche was at age 13; her subsequent periods have occurred regularly, every 28 to 30 days, until this onset of amenorrhea.
She has no history of sexually transmitted infections. She began taking an oral contraceptive pill at age 24 and discontinued it 2 months ago in the hopes of conceiving a child. Recent home pregnancy tests have been negative. She has had no vaginal bleeding, discharge, spotting, or hot flashes.
On examination, her height is 165 cm, her weight is 72 kg, and her BMI is 26. She has facial acne but no acanthosis nigricans, skin tags, galactorrhea, or increased hair growth on her chin, upper lip, chest, back, or abdomen. The remainder of her examination is normal.
A qualitative urine pregnancy test performed in the office is negative.
To continue to evaluate this patient’s condition, which one of the following next steps is most appropriate?

choices.text: Measure her serum human chorionic gonadotropin level
Continue to monitor her for one more month
Measure her follicle-stimulating hormone and estradiol levels

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Measurement of the 17-hydroxyprogesterone level can rule out congenital adrenal hyperplasia that, although an uncommon cause of secondary amenorrhea, can have a variable presentation. Transvaginal ultrasonography, measurement of the 17-hydroxypregesterone level, or measuring follicle-stimulating hormone and estradiol levels could be pursued as part of a workup for secondary amenorrhea if menses do not resume within 90 days after discontinuation of the oral contraceptive pill.

B) INCORRECT:

Measuring the serum human chorionic gonadotropin level is not necessary, given the patient’s negative qualitative pregnancy test. The sensitivity of qualitative pregnancy testing is high, and quantitative testing is required only if it is important to measure absolute hormone levels (such as with an ectopic pregnancy).

C) INCORRECT:

Transvaginal ultrasonography can be used to evaluate the endometrium and rule out a mechanical obstruction. Transvaginal ultrasonography, measurement of the 17-hydroxypregesterone level, or measuring follicle-stimulating hormone and estradiol levels could be pursued as part of a workup for secondary amenorrhea if menses do not resume within 90 days after discontinuation of the oral contraceptive pill.

D) CORRECT:

After discontinuing an oral contraceptive pill, most women resume their menses within 3 months. A study of 187 such women showed that 40.1%, 94.6%, and 98.9% had resumption of menses within 30, 60, and 90 days, respectively. A patient with a 2-month history of amenorrhea after discontinuing an oral contraceptive pill should be monitored for one more month before any further workup is undertaken.

Key learning point: After a patient discontinues use of an oral contraceptive pill, amenorrhea can last for up to 3 months; a longer duration warrants further workup.

E) INCORRECT:

Measuring the follicle-stimulating hormone and estradiol levels may be helpful in distinguishing between central and primary ovarian insufficiency. Transvaginal ultrasonography, measurement of the 17-hydroxypregesterone level, or measuring follicle-stimulating hormone and estradiol levels could be pursued as part of a workup for secondary amenorrhea if menses do not resume within 90 days after discontinuation of the oral contraceptive pill.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old woman reports that she has not been menstruating for the past 5 months. Previously, her menses were monthly since menarche at the age of 12 years. Several home pregnancy tests have been negative. She reports some vaginal dryness and night sweats. She does not smoke or have a family history of thromboembolic disorders.
Her blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg. Her thyroid is homogeneous and normal in size. She has no expressible fluid in her breasts, no acne, and no hirsutism.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range



Follicle-stimulating hormone (mIU/mL)
50
Follicular phase, 3–20Ovulatory phase, 9–26Luteal phase, 1–12Postmenopausal, 18–153



Luteinizing hormone (mIU/mL)
72
Follicular phase, 2–15Ovulatory phase, 22–105Luteal phase, 0.6–19Postmenopausal, 16–64


Estradiol (pg/mL)
9
Follicular phase, <20–145Midcycle peak, 112–443Luteal phase, <20–241Postmenopausal, <59


A test for human chorionic gonadotropin is negative. Karyotype analysis is normal.
Which one of the following additional tests should be performed in this patient?

choices.text: Measurement of thyroid-stimulating hormone and thyroid peroxidase antibodies

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Primary ovarian insufficiency is characterized by secondary amenorrhea and premature menopause (i.e., before age 40). No specific menstrual pattern is associated with this disorder, but patients may have a sudden cessation of menses. Patients may also have symptoms of menopause, including hot flashes, vaginal dryness, and insomnia. Laboratory analysis typically reveals levels of follicle-stimulating hormone and luteinizing hormone that are in the postmenopausal range.

Although the cause of primary ovarian insufficiency is often unknown, it may have an autoimmune etiology and be associated with other autoimmune diseases, such as primary thyroid or adrenal disease (e.g., Hashimoto thyroiditis or Addison disease). Patients with primary ovarian insufficiency should be screened for these diseases — with measurement of the thyroid-peroxidase antibody titer and thyroid-stimulating hormone level and with an adrenal stimulation test.

Key learning point: Patients who are diagnosed with primary ovarian insufficiency should be screened for hypothyroidism.

B) INCORRECT:

A progesterone challenge is not indicated in a woman already demonstrated to have low estrogen levels.

C) INCORRECT:

Knowing the progesterone level would not affect the diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Growth-hormone abnormalities are not associated with primary ovarian insufficiency. A pituitary cause of ovarian insufficiency would be associated with low gonadotropin levels.

E) INCORRECT:

CT of the pelvis is not warranted because bilateral destruction of the ovaries by a structural abnormality is uncommon.

questions.text:
A young woman, 18 years of age, is evaluated for secondary amenorrhea. She reports menarche at age 13 with regular cycles every 28 days. During the past 2 years, her periods have become irregular and have now been absent for the past 10 months. She has never been sexually active. She reports a normal diet, does not skip meals, and does not report purging behavior or any other medical problems. She takes no medications and does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. She is a member of her school’s cross-country team and is very physically active.
On examination, she is 165 cm tall and weighs 48 kg; her BMI is 17.6. Her blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg, and she has a resting heart rate of 60 beats per minute. She is thin and appears comfortable. She has no hirsutism or acne, and her oral mucosa is moist without erosions. Her pelvic examination reveals normal anatomy; her vaginal mucosa is erythematous and thin. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable.
Her laboratory results are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range


Thyroid-stimulating hormone (μU/mL)
1.1
0.5–4.7


Free thyroxine (ng/dL)
1.4
0.8–1.8


Prolactin (ng/mL)
12
0–20


Follicle-stimulating hormone (mIU/mL)
0.05
0.64–10.98


A test for human chorionic gonadotropin in the urine is negative.
Administration of medroxyprogesterone acetate 10 mg daily for 10 days followed by withdrawal fails to induce menstrual bleeding after 3 days.
As compared to a healthy patient, this patient has a most substantially increased risk for which one of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hypothalamic amenorrhea is not associated with increased risk for breast cancer, prolactinoma, primary ovarian insufficiency, or coronary artery disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Hypothalamic amenorrhea is not associated with increased risk for breast cancer, prolactinoma, primary ovarian insufficiency, or coronary artery disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Hypothalamic amenorrhea is not associated with increased risk for breast cancer, prolactinoma, primary ovarian insufficiency, or coronary artery disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Hypothalamic amenorrhea is not associated with increased risk for breast cancer, prolactinoma, primary ovarian insufficiency, or coronary artery disease.

E) CORRECT:

This patient's secondary amenorrhea is most likely due to functional hypothalamic amenorrhea as a result of habitual strenuous exercise and low BMI. Her laboratory results exclude other common causes of secondary amenorrhea, such as pregnancy, hypothyroidism, hyperprolactinemia, and primary ovarian insufficiency. She is underweight, and her reddened, atrophic vaginal mucosa suggests estrogen deficiency, which is confirmed by the failure of progesterone withdrawal to provoke menstrual bleeding. Estrogen deficiency can cause young women to fail to attain peak bone mass; as a result, they are at risk for low bone density with future osteoporosis and fractures. These patients are often described as having the female athlete triad of inadequate caloric intake (with or without an eating disorder), amenorrhea, and low bone density.

Key learning point: The clinical syndrome known as the female athlete triad refers to inadequate caloric intake (with or without an eating disorder), amenorrhea, and low bone density.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old woman with no significant medical history reports that her menses have been heavier and more painful for the past 3 years. She states that her menses have always lasted for 5 days, but now she is bleeding for 7 days and passing clots the size of oranges for 4 of the 7 days. The cramping pain of her menses has responded well to treatment with ibuprofen. She denies feeling tired or lightheaded.
On examination, her vital signs are normal. Bimanual examination reveals a mildly enlarged uterus without any specific mass lesions.
Which one of the following tests is most appropriate to evaluate this patient?

choices.text: Measurement of estradiol and follicle-stimulating hormone levels

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hysteroscopy is appropriate for women with suspected intrauterine pathology where a biopsy is indicated. Hysteroscopy would not precede a pelvic ultrasound in a 37-year-old woman with abnormal uterine bleeding.

B) INCORRECT:

Endometrial biopsy is not indicated for a premenopausal woman with regular menstrual cycles. Endometrial biopsy is generally used to investigate dysfunctional uterine bleeding in women who are at least 45 years old, women with a history of exposure to unopposed estrogen, and women with an abnormally thickened endometrium on pelvic ultrasound.

C) INCORRECT:

Estradiol and follicle-stimulating hormone levels would help differentiate perimenopause from primary ovarian insufficiency, but measuring these levels is not indicated for the evaluation of abnormal uterine bleeding.

D) CORRECT:

The normal menstrual cycle lasts 21 to 35 days; the normal duration of flow is about 5 days with less than 80 mL of blood lost. Abnormal uterine bleeding is bleeding that is abnormal in flow or cycle. Menorrhagia is cyclical heavy menstrual bleeding. The most common causes of abnormal uterine bleeding include anatomical uterine pathologies, such as endometrial polyps, adenomyosis, uterine leiomyomas, endometrial hyperplasia, and endometrial carcinoma.

The optimal approach to investigating abnormal uterine bleeding has not been established for a woman with a normal-size uterus; however, a woman with an enlarged uterus should undergo imaging. A pelvic ultrasound is optimal because it provides better and more cost-effective imaging than a pelvic MRI.

Key learning point: The most appropriate test to evaluate a premenopausal woman with recent menorrhagia and an enlarged uterus is pelvic ultrasound.

E) INCORRECT:

The optimal approach to investigating abnormal uterine bleeding has not been established for a woman with a normal-size uterus; however, a woman with an enlarged uterus should undergo imaging. A pelvic ultrasound is optimal because it provides better and more cost-effective imaging than a pelvic MRI.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old woman presents with a 2-day history of abdominal pain. She describes the pain as cramping with radiation to her lower back and rates it at 7 out of 10 in intensity. She has also experienced nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and diffuse headache during the past 2 days. She reports having similar symptoms with her last menstrual period 28 days ago but did not seek medical care at the time because the symptoms resolved once her period ended.
She has had no vision changes, fevers, chills, sick contacts, dysuria, hematuria, increased urinary frequency, or changes in bowel movements. She reports that she reached menarche at age 14 and that her menstrual periods are regular, every 29 to 30 days. She is not sexually active, is not taking oral contraceptive pills, and does not wish to take them given her religious beliefs. She reports a well-balanced diet without any recent dietary changes, and she does not smoke or drink alcohol.
On physical examination, her temperature is 37°C, her blood pressure is 105/67 mm Hg, her heart rate is 76 beats per minute, and she is breathing comfortably on room air. Her abdomen is soft and nondistended, but there is mild tenderness to light palpation at her lower abdomen. There is no tenderness at the costovertebral angle. The external genitalia appear normal.
An in-office pregnancy test is negative.
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Antibiotics for a urinary tract infection

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient is presenting with primary dysmenorrhea — defined as painful menstruation without an underlying pelvic pathology, such as endometriosis or fibroids. Primary dysmenorrhea can develop within 2 years of menarche for some adolescents, and symptoms typically dissipate with age. The pain, usually located in the suprapubic region, is typically described as cramping with fluctuating intensity and occasional radiation to the back. Associated symptoms include nausea, vomiting, bloating, and diarrhea. The pain peaks 24 to 36 hours before the onset of menses.

Identifying and treating primary dysmenorrhea is important because it is correlated with reduced quality of life, poorer mood, and poorer sleep quality during menstruation. The diagnosis can usually be made based on history and physical examination. Imaging is not needed if there are no features on history or physical examination to indicate a secondary cause of dysmenorrhea. However, a transvaginal ultrasound can be performed if there is concern for a secondary cause or if the physical examination is limited by body habitus.

First-line treatment options include nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) and combination oral contraceptive pills (OCPs). Although combination OCPs have the added advantage of providing contraception, NSAIDs are the most appropriate option in this patient who does not wish to use birth control. NSAIDs provide pain relief through interruption of cyclooxygenase activity and suppression of prostaglandin production. They should be started 1 to 2 days before the anticipated onset of the patient’s next menstrual period and continued on a fixed schedule for 2 to 3 days. If the patient’s symptoms do not improve with appropriate doses of NSAIDs over two to three cycles, then a discussion with her regarding a trial of combination OCPs may be warranted.

Key learning point: First-line therapy for primary dysmenorrhea consists of nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs or combination oral contraceptive pills.

B) INCORRECT:

Although this patient is experiencing lower abdominal pain and diarrhea, these symptoms are more likely to be related to the onset of menses than to gastrointestinal disease, given their cyclical nature. In addition, the patient reports no significant dietary deviations from a well-balanced diet, making increased fiber intake unnecessary.

C) INCORRECT:

Although antiemetics can be used as adjunctive therapy for symptom relief, they are not first-line treatment for primary dysmenorrhea.

D) INCORRECT:

Migraine headaches are typically characterized as unilateral, severe, throbbing pain accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and photosensitivity. This patient has diffuse pain that is not associated with vision changes, making migraine a less likely diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Urinary tract infections can manifest with lower abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting; however, patients usually report dysuria, hematuria, or increased urinary frequency. This patient does not endorse any of these symptoms, and she is afebrile on examination; antibiotics are therefore not appropriate.

questions.text:
A healthy 18-year-old female cross-country runner presents for her preparticipation physical. On a questionnaire about her health during the past 2 years, she reports that she was held out of competition once for a stress reaction in her tibia. She reached menarche at age 13 but has had only two periods in the past 12 months; the last one was 5 months ago. She has never been sexually active.
Her BMI is 17.5. Her physical examination is within normal limits.
Laboratory testing reveals a normal complete blood count; normal renal function, liver function, and thyroid function; normal electrolyte and prolactin levels; negative results for human chorionic gonadotropin; and low or low-normal levels of luteinizing hormone, follicle-stimulating hormone, and estradiol.
Which one of the following initial tests, if any, is indicated for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A pelvic ultrasound can be obtained in patients with clinical or biochemical hyperandrogenism to confirm polycystic ovaries and rule out virilizing tumors. This test is not necessary in a patient with a normal physical examination.

B) CORRECT:

Young female athletes are at risk for low energy availability, menstrual dysfunction, and low bone mineral density — the so-called female athlete triad. The presence of any one component of the triad should trigger evaluation for the other components. Early intervention is critical to prevent progression of any of the triad components to more serious outcomes.

In this case, the patient has amenorrhea and a low BMI — and should therefore be evaluated for low bone mineral density. The indications for bone densitometry in a female athlete are as follows:

• History of a diagnosed eating disorder
• BMI ≤17.5, body weight <85% expected for age (adolescents only), or recent weight loss of ≥10% in one month
• Menarche at ≥16 years of age or <6 menses during a 12-month period
• Two prior stress reactions or fractures, one high-risk stress reaction or fracture, or a low-energy nontraumatic fracture
• A prior Z-score of less than −2 on bone densitometry

Initial evaluation for a patient with amenorrhea should also include a complete blood count and measurement of human chorionic gonadotropin, electrolytes, glucose, bicarbonate, blood urea nitrogen, creatinine, liver enzymes, and (when appropriate) inflammatory markers such as erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein. In addition, an endocrine evaluation should be performed, including serum levels of thyroid-stimulating hormone, free thyroxine, prolactin, luteinizing hormone, follicle-stimulating hormone, estradiol, and antimüllerian hormone. Androgen levels can also be assessed if there is clinical evidence of hyperandrogenism. Finally, a progesterone challenge test is recommended to induce withdrawal bleeding (as an indication of chronic estrogen exposure) and to ensure the integrity of the outflow tract.

Key learning point: A young woman who is suspected of having the female athlete triad because of amenorrhea and a low BMI should undergo bone densitometry.

C) INCORRECT:

Young female athletes are at risk for low energy availability, menstrual dysfunction, and low bone mineral density — the so-called female athlete triad. The presence of any one component of the triad should trigger evaluation for the other components. Early intervention is critical to prevent progression of any of the triad components to more serious outcomes.

D) INCORRECT:

Fecal calprotectin levels are used to aid in the evaluation of chronic diarrhea and inflammatory bowel disease, but they are not typically obtained in the absence of gastrointestinal symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

Urinary N-telopeptide is a biochemical marker of bone turnover that can be used to monitor patients on bisphosphonate therapy. It is not included in the initial workup of female athlete triad.

questions.text:
A 13-year-old girl who reached menarche 7 months ago reports irregular periods. Her first two periods were about 30 days apart and lasted 4 to 5 days each. In the subsequent months, she has either missed periods altogether or had two discrete bleeding episodes within the same month, each lasting 6 days. She reports no dysmenorrhea and has used no more than four sanitary pads during any 24-hour interval.
She is physically active, reports no fatigue, and is otherwise well. She reports no sexual activity and has no significant family medical history. Her only medication is a daily multivitamin.
Her heart rate is 72 beats per minute, and her blood pressure is 105/65 mm Hg. Her height is 155 cm, and her BMI is in the 60th percentile. Breast development and pubic hair are both consistent with sexual maturity rating (Tanner stage) 4. She has no abnormal skin findings. The result of a beta human chorionic gonadotropin test is negative.
Which one of the following conditions is the most likely cause of this patient’s irregular periods?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Prolactinomas of the pituitary gland secrete excess prolactin, leading to amenorrhea, oligomenorrhea or, less commonly, galactorrhea. Although possible, a prolactinoma is much less likely than anovulatory cycles to be the cause of this young adolescent’s irregular periods in the first year after menarche.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with Turner syndrome typically have hypogonadism with limited breast development and primary amenorrhea. A small percentage may menstruate, but Turner syndrome is much less likely in this patient who has normal height and breast development.

C) INCORRECT:

Various types of vaginal septa can initially manifest at the time of menarche. For example, a transverse septum can manifest as hematocolpos, and a longitudinal septum can manifest as bleeding despite tampon use (because the tampon is placed in one half of a divided vagina). However, vaginal septa would not lead to the irregular periods seen in this case.

D) CORRECT:

In the first postmenarchal year, the most common cause of irregular menstrual bleeding in an otherwise healthy girl is anovulatory cycles, because the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis feedback loops are not yet mature. Most menstrual cycles range from 21 to 45 days, last ≤7 days, and require three to six sanitary pads or tampons per 24-hour interval.

Pregnancy is a key cause of amenorrhea and should be tested for, as in this case.

Natural History of Anovulatory Cycles

Anovulatory cycles are most common in the months after menarche and are typically followed with watchful waiting. However, further workup is recommended for patients who demonstrate any of the following menstrual cycle abnormalities:

• The development of markedly irregular periods after establishment of regular monthly periods
• Amenorrhea lasting >90 days
• Periods lasting >7 days
• Heavy periods requiring frequent pad or tampon changes (soaking through more than one pad or tampon every 1 to 2 hours)

Key learning point: In the first postmenarchal year, the most common cause of irregular menstrual bleeding is anovulatory cycles.

E) INCORRECT:

Young women with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) present with amenorrhea or oligomenorrhea and signs of hyperandrogenism, including hirsutism and acne. Although this patient may end up having PCOS, irregular bleeding in the first postmenarchal year is more likely because of the immature hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis. If the patient’s irregular cycles continue, she can be evaluated for PCOS.

questions.text:
A 15-year-old girl who reached menarche approximately 2 years ago and is generally healthy reports moderate-to-severe pain with menstruation. During the past 5 months, she has developed abdominal pain, cramping, lower back pain, and nausea during her periods. For the past 3 months, she has had to miss school on the first day of each menstrual cycle because of the pain.
Her periods last 4 to 5 days and occur every 29 days. She uses three to five regular tampons in 24 hours. She has no midcycle bleeding or unusual vaginal discharge. She rates her maximum pain at 7 to 8 on a 10-point scale. She has intermittently used acetaminophen (325 mg to 650 mg) and heat packs, with little relief. She takes no other medications, has no allergies, and is not sexually active.
Her examination is within normal limits.
What is the most appropriate management for this patient’s dysmenorrhea?

choices.text: Recommend use of a nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug around the start of each menstrual period

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

For patients with primary dysmenorrhea who are sexually active, oral contraceptives may be considered first-line treatment because they can simultaneously alleviate symptoms and serve as birth control.

B) INCORRECT:

No data support specific dietary or exercise routines in the management of primary dysmenorrhea.

C) INCORRECT:

Hormonal intrauterine devices and hormonal implants may be considered second-line therapy in sexually active patients but are not appropriate for first-line treatment.

D) CORRECT:

Primary dysmenorrhea refers to painful menses in the absence of pelvic disease. It can cause abdominal, back, and thigh pain and may be associated with nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and headache. It generally manifests 2 to 3 years after menarche, when ovulatory cycles become regular, and is graded based on symptom severity and interference with daily activities.

Primary dysmenorrhea involves secretion of prostaglandins that affect the uterus and the gastrointestinal tract. Inhibition of prostaglandin synthesis with nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) has been shown to improve symptoms of primary dysmenorrhea; notably, acetaminophen does not have the same effect.

For this patient, who is not yet sexually active, NSAIDs should be started 1 to 2 days before the anticipated onset of her next menstrual period and continued on a fixed schedule for 2 to 3 days. If symptoms do not improve with appropriate doses of NSAIDs over two to three cycles, a trial of combination oral contraceptives may be indicated as second-line therapy for those who can take estrogen.

Midcycle bleeding, new vaginal discharge, severe menstrual pain since menarche, failure of first-line management options, or a strong family history of gynecologic disorders, such as endometriosis, should prompt further investigation for causes of secondary dysmenorrhea and possible referral to gynecology.

Key learning point: The most appropriate first-line management strategy for primary dysmenorrhea is nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs.

E) INCORRECT:

For patients with primary dysmenorrhea who are sexually active, depot medroxyprogesterone acetate may simultaneously alleviate symptoms and serve as birth control and is a potentially effective alternative to oral contraceptives.

questions.text:
A 15-year-old girl who reached menarche at age 13 reports that she has not had her menstrual period in 7 months. She has no significant medical history, takes no medications, and reports that she is not sexually active. She reports no fevers, night sweats, skin symptoms, or gastrointestinal symptoms but does acknowledge some intolerance to cold and hair thinning.
She is in the ninth grade and does well in school. During the past year, she became very active on the school track team and has eliminated all gluten and processed sugars from her diet in order to "be as healthy as [she\] can be.” In addition to running regularly, she swims for 2 hours three times per week.
On examination, her BMI is at the third percentile, and her weight is down about 4.5 kg from her last visit 9 months ago. She has a temperature of 36.1°C, a heart rate of 55 beats per minute, and a respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute. Pubic hair and breast development are both consistent with sexual maturity rating (Tanner stage) 4. The rest of the examination is normal.
A urine pregnancy test is negative. Screening blood tests are ordered.
Which one of the following laboratory findings is most likely to be associated with this patient's amenorrhea?

choices.text: Elevated tissue transglutaminase immunoglobulin A antibody level

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with anorexia nervosa may have thyroid abnormalities similar to those seen with euthyroid sick syndrome, including a low-to-normal level of thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH). Patients may also experience symptoms such as thinning hair, dry skin, and temperature intolerance. An elevated TSH level is associated with hypothyroidism, which is in turn typically associated with weight gain, not weight loss.

B) INCORRECT:

Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) is a possible cause of menstrual irregularities in adolescents and can be associated with an elevated insulin level. However, patients with PCOS usually have evidence of hyperandrogenism (hirsutism, acne) on examination, and most patients with PCOS are not underweight.

C) INCORRECT:

Prolactin levels should be checked in cases of secondary amenorrhea. An elevated prolactin level, which can be seen with a prolactinoma or with use of certain antipsychotic medications, may be associated with amenorrhea, but it is a less likely cause of amenorrhea in this case, given the history suggestive of an eating disorder.

D) INCORRECT:

Celiac disease, which is associated with an elevated level of tissue transglutaminase immunoglobulin A antibody, can manifest with weight loss and secondary amenorrhea, but there are typically gastrointestinal symptoms as well. This patient has already eliminated gluten from her diet, making celiac disease an unlikely cause of her amenorrhea.

E) CORRECT:

Evaluation of secondary amenorrhea should always begin with a pregnancy test. If that is negative (as in this case), alternative causes should be explored. This patient has secondary amenorrhea, bradycardia, and weight loss with a BMI at the third percentile in the context of increased intense exercise and dietary restrictions. This clinical picture should raise suspicion for an eating disorder, in particular anorexia nervosa, restricting type.

Anorexia nervosa is characterized by a substantial restriction in caloric intake leading to weight loss and potentially a significantly low body weight for one's age and height. Affected patients have a distorted body image and an intense fear of gaining weight or being fat. Secondary amenorrhea can be a medical complication of anorexia nervosa but is no longer a criterion for diagnosis of anorexia nervosa.

Patients with restrictive eating disorders and nutritional imbalance have hypothalamic suppression and, as a result, typically have low or low-to-normal levels of gonadotropins and sex hormones. Thus, this patient would be expected to have a low level of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH).

Bone densitometry should also be considered in this patient, as she is at risk for the female athlete triad, which consists of low energy availability (with or without an eating disorder), amenorrhea, and osteoporosis.

Patients with a confirmed eating disorder should have a multidisciplinary treatment team that includes a nutritionist, a behavioral therapist, and a medical doctor. The nutritionist can help the patient normalize her eating and exercise patterns; the behavioral therapist can address any body dysmorphism or other psychological distress; and the medical doctor can monitor the patient's weight, vital signs, and onset or resumption of menses. An exact weight goal is difficult to project in growing adolescents. Nevertheless, normalization of vital signs, a return to previous growth-curve trajectories, and onset or resumption of menses are the expected goals of recovery.

Key learning point: The laboratory workup of an adolescent girl with amenorrhea that is secondary to a possible eating disorder is likely to show low levels of follicle-stimulating hormone.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old girl presents with concern that she has not yet started menstruating. She is on the cross-country team, runs approximately 25 miles per week, and reports eating three meals per day. She has had no headaches, dizziness, vision changes, or changes in weight. She has no significant medical history, including sport injuries or fractures.
She has a BMI of 20 and breast development consistent with sexual maturity rating (Tanner stage) 3. Her physical examination, including a pelvic examination, is otherwise normal. A urine pregnancy test is negative.
What is the most appropriate next step in this patient’s care?

choices.text: Counsel the patient about the female athlete triad, and schedule a follow-up visit in 6 months
Advise the patient to reduce her running and increase her caloric intake
Prescribe a combined oral contraceptive pill

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although the female athlete triad and RED-S should both be considered in a female athlete with delayed menarche, making these diagnoses or initiating an intervention would be inappropriate without first evaluating for other causes of amenorrhea.

B) INCORRECT:

MRI of the head is not typically required in delayed menarche unless the patient is experiencing symptoms (e.g., galactorrhea, headache, visual disturbances) that suggest an intracranial lesion such as a pituitary tumor.

C) INCORRECT:

Although the female athlete triad and RED-S should both be considered in a female athlete with delayed menarche, making these diagnoses or initiating an intervention would be inappropriate without first evaluating for other causes of amenorrhea.

D) INCORRECT:

Initiating a combined oral contraceptive pill before determining the cause of the patient’s primary amenorrhea would be inappropriate. This approach could give a false sense of improvement without addressing the underlying cause.

E) CORRECT:

This patient has delayed menarche, defined as absence of menstruation at ≥ 15 years of age. Girls who have not developed secondary sex characteristics by age 13 or started menstruating by age 15 warrant a comprehensive evaluation for primary amenorrhea.

The differential diagnosis for primary amenorrhea includes pregnancy, polycystic ovary syndrome, hyperprolactinemia, thyroid disorder, adrenal disorders, and hormonal therapies (including birth control). Another common cause of primary amenorrhea is low energy availability — specifically, the female athlete triad and relative energy deficiency in sport (RED-S).

• The female athlete triad is defined as menstrual dysfunction, low bone mineral density, and low energy availability (with or without an eating disorder).
• The term “RED-S,” which is adapted from the triad, can be applied to all athletes regardless of gender and details the effect that low energy availability can have on an athlete’s health and performance.
• The initial treatment for both conditions is lifestyle modification, which includes increased caloric intake and reduced physical activity.

Although the female athlete triad and RED-S should both be considered in a female athlete with delayed menarche, making these diagnoses or initiating an intervention would be inappropriate without first evaluating for other causes of amenorrhea. The initial workup for delayed menarche should include:

• Sexual maturity rating (Tanner staging) to assess breast maturity
• Endocrine-hormone testing (including measurement of human chorionic gonadotropin [HCG], luteinizing hormone [LH], follicle-stimulating hormone [FSH], thyroid-stimulating hormone [TSH], prolactin, and adrenal androgens) to evaluate for physiological reasons for the delay

Girls who have not yet started puberty (breast development consistent with sexual maturity rating 1) or who have some breast development but are premenarchal at this age may have delayed or stalled puberty. Gonadotropin levels provide clues to the etiology for lack of pubertal progression. Hyper gonadotropic hypogonadism, evidenced by elevations in LH and FSH levels, is a sign of gonadal insufficiency, whereas hypo gonadotropic hypogonadism signals a delay in central gonadotropin activation as seen in constitutional delay of puberty, hypopituitarism, and potentially acquired pituitary or hypothalamic suppression.

Thyroid derangements can also affect menses and pubertal development. Elevated prolactin levels may suppress the gonadal axis and thus cause amenorrhea. Elevated adrenal androgens may cause clinical hyperandrogenism and irregular menses or amenorrhea in some cases.

Key learning point: Girls who have not reached menarche by age 15 should undergo sexual maturity rating (Tanner staging) and laboratory testing to evaluate for causes of primary amenorrhea.

questions.text:
A 21-year-old woman presents with six months of amenorrhea. Menarche was at age 11, and she had spontaneous and regular menstrual periods. At age 17, she started taking a combined oral contraceptive pill (COCP) for pregnancy prevention and had normal withdrawal bleeds every 28 days. Six months ago, she stopped taking her COCP because it was making her moody. Since then, she has not had any further menstrual bleeding. She does not have headaches, visual changes, breast discharge, nausea, vomiting, or problems with urination or passing stool.
She has a history of advanced Wilms tumor that was treated successfully at age 3. Her first Pap smear was earlier this year. Cervical cytology showed atypical squamous cells that did not exclude high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesions, prompting a colposcopy that yielded reassuring results. Family history is unremarkable. She currently takes no medications. She is a senior in college and reports that she is worried about finding a job next year. She reports eating less than usual lately because of stress and notes that she has probably lost 2 to 5 kg over the past year. She does not exercise. She is sexually active with men and uses condoms. She reports no drug, alcohol, or tobacco use.
Heart rate is 50 beats per minute, and BMI is 18. Other vital signs are normal. Physical examination identifies mild facial acne. Sexual maturity rating (Tanner stage) is 5 for breast development and 5 for pubic hair. The vaginal mucosa appears thin. The rest of the examination is unremarkable. Urine human chorionic gonadotropin is negative. A complete blood count and comprehensive metabolic panel are normal. Additional laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Thyroid-stimulating hormone (μU/mL)
3.0
0.5–4.7


Prolactin (ng/mL)
10.0
3.2–20.0 (for for Tanner stage 5)



Estradiol (pg/mL)
9.2
Follicular phase: <20–145Mid-cycle peak: 112–443Luteal phase: <20–241



Follicle-stimulating hormone (mIU/mL)
80.4
Follicular phase: 2.5–10.2Mid-cycle peak: 3.1–17.7Luteal phase: 1.5–9.1


What is the most likely primary explanation for this patient’s menstrual dysfunction?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Functional hypothalamic amenorrhea is due to suppression of the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis (with low or normal FSH levels) as a result of insufficient caloric intake, excessive exercise, or psychological stress. While the patient's reported eating habits, stress, weight loss, low BMI, and low heart rate may indicate an eating disorder, the elevated FSH level is not consistent with this diagnosis as the cause of her amenorrhea.

B) CORRECT:

The workup of secondary amenorrhea should always start with a pregnancy test; if it is negative, levels of prolactin, thyroid-stimulating hormone, estradiol, and FSH should be measured.

Although low estradiol levels are normal during certain phases of the menstrual cycle, the presence of clinical features of hypoestrogenism — such as vaginal atrophy and amenorrhea — indicate chronically low estradiol. Hypoestrogenism with a high FSH level is consistent with hypergonadotropic hypogonadism (primary hypogonadism). In a premenopausal woman, the most likely cause of hypergonadotropic hypogonadism is primary ovarian insufficiency (POI), formerly known as premature ovarian failure. POI is characterized by a significant decline in ovarian follicles and function before the age of 40 years. The most common presenting symptom of POI is primary or secondary amenorrhea, but many individuals also experience menopausal symptoms such as hot flashes, vaginal dryness, sleep disturbances, and mood changes. If the estradiol level is low and the FSH is elevated on initial testing and repeat testing one month later, POI is diagnosed.

While most cases of POI are idiopathic, some may be iatrogenic. Abdominal radiation and certain chemotherapeutic agents (e.g., cyclophosphamide, carboplatin), which may have been a part of this patient’s treatment regimen as a child, increase the risk of ovarian insufficiency. Other causes of POI include genetic abnormalities (e.g., fragile X premutation, Turner syndrome, mosaicism) and autoimmune oophoritis; toxic, metabolic, and infectious causes are rare.

Complications of POI include those of chronic hypoestrogenism such as osteoporosis and cardiovascular disease. Treatment for POI includes prompt initiation of combined hormone replacement therapy at doses higher than those for typical menopause symptoms. In addition, individuals with POI should receive psychological support for this emotionally challenging diagnosis, counseling on options for fertility and contraception (some women may continue to have intermittent ovulation), and treatment for any associated conditions.

Key learning point: In a woman younger than 40 years, primary ovarian insufficiency is the most common cause of hypergonadotropic hypogonadism.

C) INCORRECT:

Cervical stenosis, which can occur after certain cervical procedures (e.g., conization, loop electrosurgical excision procedure) or pelvic radiation, is a cause of secondary amenorrhea. However, cervical stenosis does not manifest with low estrogen or elevated FSH levels.

D) INCORRECT:

Post-pill amenorrhea is the delayed return of normal menses after stopping combined oral contraceptives, likely due to secondary hypogonadism from disruption of the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis. Typically, however, hormone levels normalize and menses resume within 3 months after stopping the pill. In addition, vaginal atrophy is not expected with this condition.

E) INCORRECT:

Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), which may cause secondary amenorrhea, is characterized by excess androgen, polycystic ovaries, and/or ovulatory dysfunction. Although this patient has some acne, she does not have other signs of hyperandrogenism or metabolic syndrome, and she has no history of irregular menses. In addition, FSH levels are usually low or normal in patients with PCOS.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl comes to the office because of a 2-year history of irregular menstrual bleeding.
