Menses have occurred at irregular 45- to 60-day intervals since menarche at the age of 13 years. Her last menstrual period was 5 weeks ago and lasted for 7 days with heavy flow and no cramping. She is 171 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 58 kg (128 lb); BMI is 20 kg/m2. Her temperature is 36.6°C (97.8°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows a normal-appearing vagina and cervix. Bimanual examination shows a normal-sized uterus and no palpable adnexal masses. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with nonsecreting pituitary adenomas may present with oligomenorrhea. Nonsecreting pituitary macroadenomas can exert a mass effect on the remaining gland or the hypothalamus, resulting in oligomenorrhea due to deficient FSH and LH. However, additional signs, including headache, visual deficits, and symptoms associated with other hormone deficiencies (e.g., hypothyroidism) would also be expected. Patients with functioning (i.e., hormone-producing) adenomas (e.g., prolactinomas) present with galactorrhea, which is absent in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Endometriosis affects up to 10% of women and manifests with a variety of menstrual abnormalities. However, rather than oligomenorrhea, patients more commonly present with dysmenorrhea, premenstrual or postmenstrual bleeding. The most common symptom is chronic pelvic pain that occurs shortly before the menstrual cycle begins. Rectovaginal tenderness and adnexal masses on physical examination would also be expected.

C) INCORRECT:

Polycystic ovary syndrome is characterized by hyperandrogenism, oligoovulation or anovulation, and polycystic ovaries. Patients often present with menstrual irregularities (e.g., primary amenorrhea, oligomenorrhea, secondary amenorrhea) during adolescence. Moreover, signs of obesity, metabolic syndrome, and virilization (e.g., excess hair growth, acne) due to hyperandrogenism would be present. This patient's oligomenorrhea likely results from another underlying cause.

D) CORRECT:

Anovulatory cycles are the most common cause of abnormal uterine bleeding in otherwise healthy adolescents and typically occur up to 2 years after menarche due to an immature hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis. Anovulation leads to a deficit in progesterone production, while unopposed estrogen continues to cause abnormal growth of the endometrial lining and vessels. If increasing estrogen levels trigger negative feedback in the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis, a drop in FSH/LH and estrogen levels leads to a sudden loss of endometrium that can cause heavy and prolonged bleeding. Patients should be reassured that this phenomenon is not pathological by nature and that no further workup is required.

If oligomenorrhea is prolonged (> 2 years), further evaluation is warranted to rule out pathological causes.

E) INCORRECT:

Ovarian insufficiency is characterized by less frequent (or even absent) menstrual cycles and hypoestrogenism in women < 40 years of age. However, patients with ovarian insufficiency typically present with perimenopausal, autonomic symptoms (e.g., hot flashes, heat intolerance), and atrophic features (e.g., breast tenderness, vaginal dryness).
questions.hint: Oligomenorrhea in the first 2 years after menarche is a common finding in otherwise healthy teenagers.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman reports headaches and difficulty sleeping for the past 2 days. She states that she has had similar symptoms over the past year and that they occur every month around the same time. The episodes are frequently accompanied by decreased concentration, angry feelings, and cravings for sweet foods. She says that during these episodes she is unable to work efficiently and often has arguments with her colleagues and friends. Menses occur at regular 26-day intervals and last for 5 days. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 8 years. Her vital signs are within normal limits. The patient is oriented to person, place, and time. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) is indicated in both PMS and PMDD to alleviate affective symptoms. However, CBT alone has not been shown to completely resolve moderate or severe symptoms associated with these conditions and is therefore insufficient as a monotherapy. CBT can be used as an adjunct therapy in patients who do not benefit from pharmacological treatment.

B) INCORRECT:

A copper intrauterine device (IUD) is an effective birth control method that can be offered to patients who prefer hormone-free contraception. However, this patient requires management for more than birth control. This patient meets the criteria for PMDD and requires different management.

C) INCORRECT:

Nicotine has been shown to be an individual triggering factor for PMS symptoms, and its avoidance may therefore be helpful. However, nicotine cessation is not the first-line therapy for PMDD and would likely not provide sufficient relief for this patient's severe symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

Naproxen is indicated to alleviate symptoms associated with PMS (e.g., headaches, breast tenderness, abdominal cramps). While this patient may benefit from NSAIDs for her headaches, she requires a different treatment to manage her PMDD symptoms.

E) CORRECT:

Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs; e.g., sertraline) are recommended by the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists as first-line therapy for PMDD because they have been shown to alleviate physical and affective symptoms with minimal side effects. This patient has recurrent premenstrual episodes with severe symptoms and behavioral changes that cause a clinically significant disturbance in daily life. Therefore, treatment with SSRIs is indicated. This patient should also be advised to quit smoking, which is a known trigger for PMS. Additionally, NSAIDs can be recommended to alleviate her headaches.

Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) are an alternative first-line therapy for patients who desire contraception. OCPs suppress ovulation, thereby reducing somatic and affective symptoms.
questions.hint: This patient's recurrent episodes of headaches, sleep disturbance, difficulty concentrating, and marked anger with increased interpersonal conflicts occur every month in the week before the onset of menses. Her symptoms are consistent with premenstrual dysphoric disorder (PMDD), a severe form of premenstrual syndrome (PMS).

questions.text: A previously healthy 28-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, comes to the office because she has not had a menstrual period for 4 months. She had a spontaneous abortion 10 months ago. Medical history is also remarkable for an abnormal Pap smear treated with loop electrosurgical excision 2 years ago. She is a competitive triathlon athlete and has been training for an upcoming long-distance triathlon. Her BMI is 18 kg/m2. Physical examination, including pelvic examination, shows no abnormalities. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's amenorrhea?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Primary ovarian insufficiency (POI) can develop in a 28-year-old female patient and manifest with secondary amenorrhea due to follicular depletion. However, POI also manifests with vaginal dryness, night sweats, hot flashes, dyspareunia, and irritability, none of which are seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Intrauterine adhesions can occur following trauma to the endometrium during uterine procedures or prolonged intrauterine inflammation and manifest with secondary amenorrhea and pregnancy loss. While this patient has a history of a loop electrosurgical excision procedure, intrauterine adhesions are most commonly seen in patients after uterine dilation and curettage. Moreover, patients with uterine adhesions typically experience abnormal uterine bleeding and pelvic pain, which is not seen here. In addition, this patient has no history (of features) that would suggest prolonged intrauterine inflammation (e.g., pelvic inflammatory disease, chorioamnionitis, endometritis).

C) INCORRECT:

Tumoral production of prolactin is found in patients with a pituitary prolactinoma, which can cause secondary amenorrhea due to suppression of GnRH. However, prolactinomas also manifest with galactorrhea and mass effect (e.g., bilateral hemianopsia, headaches), none of which are seen here.

D) CORRECT:

Functional hypothalamic amenorrhea (FHA) is typically caused by strenuous physical exercise, reduced caloric intake, and/or excessive stress, which leads to decreased leptin and increased cortisol with a consequent decrease in the pulsatile release of GnRH from the hypothalamus. The decreased pulsatile release of GnRH leads to a decrease in FSH and LH secretion, and therefore, a decrease in the production of estrogen, which inhibits normal ovulation and causes amenorrhea. FHA is a diagnosis of exclusion; other causes of amenorrhea, such as pregnancy, primary ovarian insufficiency, hypothyroidism, and hyperprolactinemia must first be ruled out. Treatment usually consists of lifestyle changes (e.g., stress reduction, improving nutrition, increasing BMI > 19 kg/m2). Patients can also be offered pulsatile GnRH or gonadotropin therapy to induce ovulation.

E) INCORRECT:

Anabolic steroid abuse, which is often seen in professional athletes, can cause secondary amenorrhea due to suppression of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis. However, affected patients typically also present with signs of virilization (e.g., voice deepening, hirsutism, male-pattern hair loss, increased muscle mass, clitoromegaly), none of which are seen here.
questions.hint: Women of reproductive age who are underweight or do not consume enough calories (often competitive athletes) can develop amenorrhea due to hypothalamic hypogonadism.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 3-month history of pain during intercourse and vaginal dryness. The patient has also had intermittent hot flashes and fatigue during this time. Over the past year, her periods have become irregular. Her last menstrual period was over 6 months ago. She has a history of acute lymphoblastic leukemia during childhood, which has remained in remission. Pelvic examination shows an atrophic cervix and vagina. A urinary pregnancy test is negative. A progestin challenge test is performed and shows no withdrawal bleeding. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Decreased luteinizing hormone (LH) levels are seen in hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, which can be congenital (e.g., Kallmann syndrome) or acquired (e.g., excessive exercise, reduced caloric intake, stress, pituitary lesions). While cases of acquired hypogonadotropic hypogonadism cause secondary amenorrhea, the absence of a history of excessive exercise or eating disorders and the presence of vaginal dryness and hot flashes (which are atypical for these conditions) make hypogonadotropic hypogonadism unlikely. Furthermore, this patient's presentation is highly suggestive of primary ovarian insufficiency, in which the loss of feedback inhibition of estrogen on gonadotropin (e.g., FSH, LH) secretion results in elevated serum levels of these hormones.

B) INCORRECT:

Decreased estrogen levels in ovarian failure result in increased follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) levels due to the loss of feedback inhibition of estrogen on gonadotropin secretion. As a result, the ratio of FSH to estrogen would be high in a patient with suspected primary ovarian failure.

C) CORRECT:

Primary ovarian insufficiency manifests with decreased estrogen levels as well as elevated FSH levels due to loss of feedback inhibition from estrogen on gonadotropin secretion from the anterior pituitary.

While most cases of POI are idiopathic, known causes include treatment with radiation and/or chemotherapy (this patient has a history of acute lymphoblastic leukemia during childhood) and certain genetic disorders (e.g., Turner syndrome, fragile X syndrome).

D) INCORRECT:

Testosterone levels and other androgens are usually increased in cases of polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS), which can also manifest with secondary amenorrhea. However, this patient lacks other typical manifestations of PCOS, such as hirsutism, acne vulgaris, obesity, or metabolic syndrome. Hot flashes and vaginal dryness are not typically seen in PCOS.

E) INCORRECT:

Increased TSH is seen in primary hypothyroidism, which can also manifest with secondary amenorrhea and fatigue. However, this patient lacks other typical features of hypothyroidism, such as weight gain, cold intolerance, dry skin, constipation.
questions.hint: This patient presents with secondary amenorrhea and features of low estrogen levels (hot flashes, vaginal dryness) before the age of 40, which should raise concern for primary ovarian insufficiency.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman reports not having had her menstrual period for the past 6 months. During this time, she has had frequent headaches, difficulty sleeping, and increased sweating. She has not had any weight changes. Over the past year, menses occurred at irregular 30- to 45-day intervals with light flow. The patient underwent two successful cesarean deliveries at the ages of 28 and 32 years. She has two healthy children. She is sexually active with her husband and they do not use contraception. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show low estrogen and elevated FSH and LH levels. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The low T3/T4 levels associated with primary hypothyroidism cause a compensatory increase of thyroid-stimulating hormone and thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH). TRH stimulates prolactin production, which then leads to a suppression of LH and FSH. Therefore, primary hypothyroidism can indeed cause amenorrhea, but it would be associated with low LH and FSH levels. Additionally, other typical features, such as fatigue, weight gain, cold intolerance, dry skin, and hair loss, would be expected.

B) INCORRECT:

Hyperprolactinemia causes amenorrhea and is associated with signs of mass effect (headache). However, it would also manifest with other symptoms such as galactorrhea, signs of hypogonadism, and possibly bitemporal hemianopsia. Moreover, patients with hyperprolactinemia normally present with high prolactin levels and low FSH and LH levels.

C) INCORRECT:

Pregnancy should be suspected in any woman of reproductive age who presents with amenorrhea and is otherwise healthy. However, pregnancy would be associated with low FSH and LH levels, as well as high prolactin levels. Moreover, in pregnancy, a suprapubic mass (the gravid uterus) would be palpable by the 4th month of amenorrhea.

D) CORRECT:

Primary ovarian insufficiency (POI), also known as premature ovarian failure, is inadequate ovarian function in women below the age of 40 years. Patients with POI typically present with hypergonadotropic hypogonadism (high FSH and LH levels, low estrogen levels) and climacteric features (headache, impaired sleep, increased sweating) followed by amenorrhea. POI also explains why this patient has not conceived again despite not using contraception. Treatment of POI includes hormone replacement therapy.

E) INCORRECT:

Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) can manifest with amenorrhea and mood changes. However, other typical features of PCOS, such as hirsutism, acne, and weight gain are not seen in this patient.
questions.hint:
This patient presents with secondary amenorrhea, very low estrogen levels, and elevated FSH and LH levels.
Low estrogen levels in conjunction with elevated FSH and LH levels in a patient with absent menses for 6 months (following irregular cycles) are consisetent with secondary amenorrhea.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl who reached menarche approximately 2 years ago and is generally healthy reports moderate-to-severe pain with menstruation. During the past 5 months, she has developed abdominal pain, cramping, lower back pain, and nausea during her periods. For the past 3 months, she has had to miss school on the first day of each menstrual cycle because of the pain. Her periods last 4 to 5 days and occur every 29 days. She uses three to five regular tampons in 24 hours. She has no midcycle bleeding or unusual vaginal discharge. She rates her maximum pain at 7 to 8 on a 10-point scale. She has intermittently used acetaminophen (325 mg to 650 mg) and heat packs, with little relief. She takes no other medications, has no allergies, and is not sexually active. Her examination is within normal limits. What is the most appropriate management for this patient’s dysmenorrhea?

choices.text: Recommend use of a nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug around the start of each menstrual period

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

For patients with primary dysmenorrhea who are sexually active, oral contraceptives may be considered first-line treatment because they can simultaneously alleviate symptoms and serve as birth control.

B) INCORRECT:

No data support specific dietary or exercise routines in the management of primary dysmenorrhea.

C) INCORRECT:

Hormonal intrauterine devices and hormonal implants may be considered second-line therapy in sexually active patients but are not appropriate for first-line treatment.

D) CORRECT:

Primary dysmenorrhea generally manifests 2 to 3 years after menarche, when ovulatory cycles become regular, and is graded based on symptom severity and interference with daily activities.

Primary dysmenorrhea involves secretion of prostaglandins that affect the uterus and the gastrointestinal tract. Inhibition of prostaglandin synthesis with nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) has been shown to improve symptoms; notably, acetaminophen does not have the same effect.

For this patient, who is not yet sexually active, NSAIDs should be started 1 to 2 days before the anticipated onset of her next menstrual period and continued on a fixed schedule for 2 to 3 days. If symptoms do not improve with appropriate doses of NSAIDs over two to three cycles, a trial of combination oral contraceptives may be indicated as second-line therapy for those who can take estrogen.

Midcycle bleeding, new vaginal discharge, severe menstrual pain since menarche, failure of first-line management options, or a strong family history of gynecologic disorders, such as endometriosis, should prompt further investigation for causes of secondary dysmenorrhea and possible referral to gynecology.

Key learning point: The most appropriate first-line management strategy for primary dysmenorrhea is nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs.

E) INCORRECT:

For patients with primary dysmenorrhea who are sexually active, depot medroxyprogesterone acetate may simultaneously alleviate symptoms and serve as birth control and is a potentially effective alternative to oral contraceptives.
questions.hint: Primary dysmenorrhea refers to painful menses in the absence of pelvic disease. It can cause abdominal, back, and thigh pain and may be associated with nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and headache.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman with no significant medical history reports that her menses have been heavier and more painful for the past 3 years. She states that her menses have always lasted for 5 days, but now she is bleeding for 7 days and passing clots the size of oranges for 4 of the 7 days. The cramping pain of her menses has responded well to treatment with ibuprofen. She denies feeling tired or lightheaded. On examination, her vital signs are normal. Bimanual examination reveals a mildly enlarged uterus without any specific mass lesions. Which one of the following tests is most appropriate to evaluate this patient?

choices.text: Measurement of estradiol and follicle-stimulating hormone levels

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hysteroscopy is appropriate for women with suspected intrauterine pathology where a biopsy is indicated. Hysteroscopy would not be performed before imaging in a 37-year-old woman with abnormal uterine bleeding.

B) INCORRECT:

Endometrial biopsy is not indicated for a premenopausal woman with regular menstrual cycles. Endometrial biopsy is generally used to investigate dysfunctional uterine bleeding in women who are at least 45 years old, women with a history of exposure to unopposed estrogen, and women with an abnormally thickened endometrium on pelvic ultrasound.

C) INCORRECT:

Estradiol and follicle-stimulating hormone levels would help differentiate perimenopause from primary ovarian insufficiency, but measuring these levels is not indicated for the evaluation of abnormal uterine bleeding.

D) CORRECT:

The normal menstrual cycle lasts 21 to 35 days; the normal duration of flow is about 5 days with less than 80 mL of blood lost. Abnormal uterine bleeding is bleeding that is abnormal in flow or cycle. The most common causes of abnormal uterine bleeding include anatomical uterine pathologies, such as endometrial polyps, adenomyosis, uterine leiomyomas, endometrial hyperplasia, and endometrial carcinoma.

The optimal approach to investigating abnormal uterine bleeding has not been established for a woman with a normal-size uterus; however, a woman with an enlarged uterus should undergo imaging. A pelvic ultrasound is optimal because it provides better and more cost-effective imaging than a pelvic MRI.

Key learning point: The most appropriate test to evaluate a premenopausal woman with recent menorrhagia and an enlarged uterus is pelvic ultrasound.

E) INCORRECT:

The optimal approach to investigating abnormal uterine bleeding in a woman with a normal-sized uterus has not been clearly established. However, in cases of an enlarged uterus, imaging is recommended. A different imaging modality is preferred over MRI due to its superior and more cost-effective results.
questions.hint: Passing of blood clots larger than 2–3 cm is a clinical indicator for heavy menstrual bleeding.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl presents with a 10-day history of vaginal bleeding. The flow is heavy with the passage of clots. Since menarche 1 year ago, menses have occurred at irregular 26- to 32-day intervals and last 3 to 6 days. Her last menstrual period was 4 weeks ago. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 106/70 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows vaginal bleeding. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Her hemoglobin is 13.1 g/dL. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral or IV tranexamic acid is a second-line agent used for treating blood loss in acute AUB when other options have failed. Tranexamic acid acts within 2–3 hours of administration and should not be used in women at a high risk of thrombosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Minimally invasive endometrial ablation is the preferred approach in hemodynamically stable women for whom medical therapy for AUB is unsuccessful or contraindicated, but it should only be performed in patients who do not wish to bear any more children. It provides long-term improvement of uterine bleeding symptoms by destroying a thin layer of the endometrium (e.g., with extreme cold, heat, or radiofrequency energy). Hysteroscopy prior to ablation may be useful for identifying and treating intrauterine structural abnormalities (e.g., polyps or fibroids).

C) INCORRECT:

Dilation and uterine curettage with concomitant hysteroscopy is the preferred approach in hemodynamically unstable women with severe AUB after immediate supportive measures (e.g., fluid resuscitation, blood transfusion) have been implemented. It is both diagnostic and therapeutic (i.e., used to identify intrauterine pathologies, take tissue samples, remove excess uterine lining) and preserves fertility as well. If performed rapidly, it may decrease bleeding in less than an hour.
Image Description:

A gynecological procedure in which the cervix is widened using dilators of increasing diameters (left image) in order to allow insertion of a curette into the uterus for therapeutic or diagnostic tissue removal (right image).

D) CORRECT:

Administration of high-dose oral conjugated estrogen is the treatment of choice in hemodynamically stable women with acute AUB, irrespective of the underlying cause. High levels of estrogen trigger rapid growth of the endometrium and thereby stop sudden, heavy bleeding from the uterine surface. Surgical treatment is needed if the patient does not respond to medical treatment or is hemodynamically unstable, bleeding is severe, medical management is contraindicated, or the underlying medical condition requires surgical repair. Conjugated estrogen therapy is contraindicated in women with breast cancer and/or those at a high risk of thrombosis.

E) INCORRECT:

An intrauterine tamponade (e.g., intrauterine balloon or gauze packing) would be the initial step to decrease severe bleeding in a hemodynamically unstable woman with acute AUB. A tamponade, in addition to intravenous fluids and blood transfusions, serves to stabilize the patient until definitive therapy can be administered.
questions.hint: Acute abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB) in a girl who attained menarche only one year ago is most likely caused by anovulation due to an immature hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman comes to the office because she has not had a menstrual period for 6 months. She is a competitive runner and has been training heavily for the past year in preparation for upcoming races. She has no family or personal history of serious illness. She has not been sexually active for the past 9 months. Her temperature is 36.9°C (98.4° F), pulse is 51/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 106/67 mm Hg. Her BMI is 18 kg/m2. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her amenorrhea?

choices.text: Poor synthetic response of ovarian cells to circulating LH and FSH
Decreased frequency of GnRH release from the hypothalamus
Increased LH release and increased ovarian androgen production

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Autoimmune destruction of thyroid cells is seen in patients with Hashimoto thyroiditis. Although hypothyroidism is also a potential cause of amenorrhea that should certainly be considered, this patient has no other symptoms that would suggest this underlying condition (e.g., weight gain, fatigue, cold intolerance). Although hypothyroidism is not the most likely cause of this patient's amenorrhea, TSH levels should be measured in all women with secondary amenorrhea to rule out this condition.

B) INCORRECT:

Poor synthetic response of ovarian cells to circulating LH and FSH is seen in patients with primary ovarian insufficiency. While patients with this condition will ultimately also develop secondary amenorrhea, they initially have intermittent ovulatory cycles and therefore irregular menstrual periods. In addition, patients often present with typical symptoms of estrogen deficiency such as hot flashes and vaginal dryness. Furthermore, the condition more frequently occurs after the age of 30.

C) INCORRECT:

Increased prolactin secretion is found in patients with a pituitary prolactinoma. The condition can also cause secondary amenorrhea, which is also seen in this patient, sometimes in conjunction with galactorrhea. However, this patient's history of excessive exercise and her low BMI make a different cause more likely. Although a prolactinoma is not the most likely cause of this patient's amenorrhea, prolactin levels should be measured in all women with secondary amenorrhea to rule out hyperprolactinemia.

D) CORRECT:

Functional hypothalamic amenorrhea (FHA) is a common cause of amenorrhea in underweight women of reproductive age. FHA can be caused by a variety of factors, such as excessive exercise, reduced caloric intake, or emotional stress. In response to the decreased energy availability in these states, the body regulates the reproductive potential down by decreasing the frequency of GnRH release from the hypothalamus, which subsequently leads to decreased secretion of gonadotropins (FSH and LH), anovulation, and secondary amenorrhea.

E) INCORRECT:

Increased LH release and increased ovarian androgen production is seen in patients with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). Although PCOS is the most common reproductive disorder in women and can also cause amenorrhea, patients are obese rather than underweight and often have acne or hirsutism.
questions.hint: Competitive female athletes often present with amenorrhea, which forms part of the “female athlete triad.”

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl presents with right lower abdominal pain for 1 day. Over the past 5 months, she has had similar episodes of mild pain that occur once a month and last 1 to 2 days. Menses occur at regular 28-day intervals with moderate intensity. Her last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F). On abdominal examination, there is mild tenderness to palpation in the right lower quadrant; no masses are palpated. Bimanual pelvic examination shows mildly tender and mildly swollen right adnexa. Laboratory studies are within the reference ranges. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Pelvic ultrasonography shows a follicle with irregular margins in the right ovary and a trace of anechoic free fluid in the pouch of Douglas. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Laparoscopic adnexal detorsion is the treatment for ovarian torsion, which may manifest with unilateral lower abdominal and/or pelvic pain and tenderness with normal laboratory findings. However, patients typically present with sudden-onset severe abdominal pain that is accompanied by nausea and vomiting rather than episodic midcycle pain. Furthermore, pelvic ultrasound would most likely show an edematous, enlarged ovary and a thickened fallopian tube.

B) INCORRECT:

Combined oral contraceptive pills are the preferred treatment for polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) in patients who do not wish to conceive. PCOS typically manifests with menstrual irregularities, signs of hyperandrogenism, and enlarged or polycystic ovaries on ultrasound. This patient has normal menstrual cycles and no evidence of hyperandrogenism (e.g., hirsutism, acne). The right ovarian enlargement is likely the result of physiologic follicular cyst rupture.

C) CORRECT:

Mittelschmerz is a common benign phenomenon in women of reproductive age that is caused by physiologic enlargement and rupture of the follicular cyst during ovulation, which leads to the release of small amount of intraperitoneal fluid and subsequent peritoneal irritation. The pain is self-limited and usually subsides within a few hours to two days. Patients should be reassured and given symptomatic treatment with NSAIDs as needed.

If symptoms do not resolve with NSAIDs, combined oral contraceptive pills (COCPs) can be used in the treatment of mittelschmerz. COCPs inhibit follicular development and subsequent ovulation, preventing the recurrence of mittelschmerz.
Image Description:

The menstrual cycle consists of two phases: the follicular and the luteal phase. The onset of menses marks the beginning of the follicular phase, which usually lasts 12–14 days but may be variable. The luteal phase begins on the day of ovulation and lasts 14 days.

During the follicular phase, FSH and LH stimulate the development of several follicles, one of which develops as the dominant follicle into the Graafian follicle. An LH surge initiates ovulation. As the oocyte reaches the fallopian tube, the ruptured follicle transforms into the corpus luteum, which produces progesterone. If no pregnancy occurs, the corpus luteum regresses and the progesterone level drops. This drop induces vasospasms in the uterine spiral arteries, ischemia, and sloughing off of the functional endometrial layer, which leads to menstrual bleeding (menstrual phase). During the proliferative phase, the endometrium is built up again in preparation for oocyte implantation during the secretory phase.

1: stages of follicle development; 2: hormone levels; 3: phases of the endometrial cycle; 4: development of the endometrium during the cycle

D) INCORRECT:

Serial serum β-hCG concentration measurements are part of the expectant management of ectopic pregnancy. An ectopic pregnancy (EP) that is located in a fallopian tube often manifests with unilateral pelvic pain and tenderness. The pain usually occurs 4–6 weeks after the last menstrual period, and patients may experience vaginal bleeding, which can be mistaken for menstruation. However, this patient has recurrent midcycle pain and does not have further signs of EP, such as breast tenderness and frequent urination. Furthermore, the negative urine pregnancy test makes an ectopic pregnancy highly unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

Intravenous antibiotic therapy (e.g., cefoxitin plus doxycycline) is indicated for tuboovarian abscess, which may manifest with unilateral lower abdominal and/or pelvic pain and tender adnexal enlargement. However, patients typically present with signs of infection (e.g., fever, leukocytosis), and pelvic ultrasound shows a complex multilocular mass rather than a ruptured follicular cyst. Furthermore, cyclical pelvic pain over several months is not characteristic of tuboovarian abscess.
questions.hint: This patient has regular menses and experiences recurrent, unilateral, lower abdominal pain during midcycle. Ultrasound shows a ruptured simple follicular cyst.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl reports intermittent episodes of sadness and irritability for the past 5 months. The episodes occur every 4–5 weeks and are accompanied by abdominal pain, bloating, and headaches. Menses occur at regular 31-day intervals. Her last menstrual period was 4 weeks ago. She denies excessive worry or difficulty concentrating. She is a member of her high school soccer team and goes to practice 4–5 times weekly. The patient is at the 21stpercentile for BMI. Vital signs are within normal limits. Abdominal examination shows mild distention; there is no tenderness, guarding, or rebound. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mittelschmerz manifests with cyclic abdominal pain, which this patient has. However, mittelschmerz is not associated with mood disturbances or headaches. Moreover, the time frame is not consistent with mittelschmerz; because this patient had her last menses 4 weeks ago, she most likely already ovulated.

B) INCORRECT:

Premenstrual dysphoric disorder (PMDD) manifests with cyclical mood disturbances, abdominal pain, bloating, and headaches, all of which are associated with menstrual periods. However, PMDD is associated with more severe psychological symptoms including hopelessness, anger, self-deprecating thoughts, and anxiety, which cause significant distress and interference in daily activities (e.g., work, school, social activities, relationships).

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with anorexia nervosa typically have low body weight and often engage in demanding physical activities, both of which are seen in this patient. However, patients with anorexia nervosa typically have a history of significant deliberate weight reduction, fear of weight gain, and excessive concern about weight and body shape, none of which is present here. Moreover, anorexia nervosa is associated with menstrual irregularities, while this patient has regular menses. In addition, anorexia nervosa is defined by a BMI < 10th percentile in pediatric patients; this's patient's BMI is at the 21st percentile.

D) INCORRECT:

Major depressive disorder (MDD) manifests with depressed mood and irritability. This patient is at increased risk of developing MDD, as her mother has been diagnosed with depression. However, while this patient's symptoms seem to be cyclical, patients with MDD present with constant symptoms. Moreover, MDD usually manifests with additional features such as sleep disturbances, anhedonia, fatigue, diminished concentration, or impaired functioning in daily activities, none of which is seen here.

E) CORRECT:

Headaches, abdominal pain and bloating, and mood disturbances that occur every 4–5 weeks suggest premenstrual syndrome (PMS). Symptoms of PMS are cyclical and can start around 5 days before and resolve within 4 days after the onset of menstruation. The diagnosis of PMS requires a clear pattern of symptoms associated with menstrual periods, for which maintaining a menstrual diary is useful. This patient presents with irritability and abdominal distention, which, given the fact that her last menstrual period was 4 weeks ago, is consistent with another episode of PMS. Preexisting endocrine (e.g., thyroid disorders) and psychiatric (e.g., major depressive disorder) conditions should be ruled out before diagnosing PMS.

See “Comparison of PMS and PMDD” table.
questions.hint: Keeping a diary could provide a valuable clue to this patient's diagnosis.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old college student presents with intermittent, crampy lower abdominal pain that usually begins on the first day of her menses and lasts two days. She occasionally feels nauseated and notes mild headaches during her period. Her menstrual cycles are otherwise regular. She denies pain with intercourse and has no abnormal vaginal discharge. Physical examination, including a pelvic exam, is normal.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Endometriosis often causes dysmenorrhea, but pain typically begins before or extends beyond menstruation. Patients may also report dyspareunia or chronic pelvic discomfort. The absence of these symptoms, along with a normal pelvic exam, makes endometriosis less likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Uterine fibroids are rare in adolescents and typically cause heavy or prolonged menstrual bleeding and an enlarged uterus, which are absent here. The patient's regular cycles and normal pelvic exam further argue against fibroids.

C) CORRECT:

Primary dysmenorrhea manifests with crampy lower abdominal pain that begins with menstruation and lasts one to two days, without identifiable pelvic pathology. Increased uterine prostaglandin production during menstruation leads to enhanced uterine contractions and vasoconstriction, causing ischemic pain. Symptoms such as nausea and headaches often accompany the pain. A normal pelvic examination supports this diagnosis by excluding anatomical abnormalities or inflammatory conditions. The temporal relationship between menses onset and symptom initiation is a key diagnostic feature, indicating a physiological menstrual process rather than an underlying organic pathology.

Key learning point: Primary dysmenorrhea is characterized by crampy lower abdominal pain beginning with the onset of menses, often accompanied by nausea, fatigue, and headache, and is not associated with pelvic pathology.

D) INCORRECT:

Pelvic inflammatory disease usually presents with cervical motion tenderness, adnexal tenderness, and abnormal vaginal discharge, none of which are present here. The pain's cyclical nature and association with menses suggest a non-infectious etiology.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old girl presents with lower abdominal cramping that starts on the first day of menstruation each month and lasts for two days. The pain is sharp and intermittent, sometimes radiating to her lower back. She reports no abnormal uterine bleeding or vaginal discharge. Physical examination, including a pelvic exam, is normal. Vital signs and laboratory studies are within normal limits.
She asks about the best way to reduce her discomfort. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Opioid analgesics are not necessary for primary dysmenorrhea, which is due to prostaglandin-induced uterine contractions. NSAIDs are effective for this condition. Opioids carry risks like sedation and dependency and are not indicated for typical menstrual pain.

B) CORRECT:

Primary dysmenorrhea is characterized by menstrual pain due to excess prostaglandins, leading to increased uterine contractions and ischemic pain. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) are the first-line treatment as they inhibit cyclooxygenase, reducing prostaglandin synthesis and alleviating pain. Administering NSAIDs at the onset of menstruation and continuing through the painful period is effective. The patient's symptoms, including cyclic pain with menstruation and a normal pelvic exam, align with primary dysmenorrhea, making NSAIDs the appropriate management.

Key learning point: The first-line treatment for primary dysmenorrhea is nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) due to their ability to reduce prostaglandin production and alleviate menstrual pain.

C) INCORRECT:

Pelvic ultrasound evaluates structural abnormalities like ovarian cysts or fibroids, which may cause secondary dysmenorrhea. This patient's history and normal pelvic exam suggest primary dysmenorrhea, not structural pathology, making ultrasound unnecessary.

D) INCORRECT:

Diagnostic laparoscopy is invasive and reserved for suspected conditions like endometriosis with abnormal findings or refractory pain. The patient's symptoms and normal exam suggest primary dysmenorrhea, not requiring surgical exploration.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman with normal pelvic exam experiences severe lower abdominal cramps during the first two days of menses for the past year. What is the best initial treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonists suppress estrogen production, useful in estrogen-driven conditions like endometriosis. However, primary dysmenorrhea is due to prostaglandin-mediated uterine contractions, not estrogen. GnRH agonists are not first-line for primary dysmenorrhea and have side effects like hot flashes and decreased bone density, making them inappropriate for a young patient with normal pelvic findings.

B) INCORRECT:

Vitamin B6 is considered for premenstrual syndrome (PMS) due to its role in neurotransmitter synthesis. However, it does not address the prostaglandin-mediated uterine contractions in primary dysmenorrhea. Vitamin B6 lacks anti-inflammatory effects and is not effective for dysmenorrhea-related pain.

C) INCORRECT:

Pelvic ultrasound detects structural abnormalities like ovarian cysts or fibroids, which cause secondary dysmenorrhea. In primary dysmenorrhea, characterized by severe menstrual cramps with a normal pelvic exam, imaging is unnecessary unless atypical findings or symptoms suggest secondary pathology.

D) CORRECT:

Primary dysmenorrhea is caused by excessive prostaglandin production during menstruation, leading to increased uterine contractions and pain. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) inhibit cyclooxygenase (COX) enzymes, reducing prostaglandin synthesis and alleviating cramps. NSAIDs are the first-line treatment for primary dysmenorrhea, providing rapid relief when started at the onset of menses. This approach is suitable for young patients with normal pelvic exams, as it directly addresses the inflammatory mediator responsible for the pain.

Key learning point: Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) are the first-line treatment for primary dysmenorrhea due to their effectiveness in reducing menstrual pain by inhibiting prostaglandin synthesis.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old girl presents with painful cramps in her lower abdomen that start on the first day of her menstrual cycle and last two to three days. She describes the pain as sharp and intermittent, accompanied by mild nausea. Her menstrual cycles occur regularly every 28 days. She is otherwise healthy, with no significant medical history. Physical examination and pelvic ultrasound show no abnormalities (see report).
Pelvic ultrasound: Normal
Which of the following interventions is most appropriate to alleviate her symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acetaminophen offers analgesic effects but lacks the anti-inflammatory properties needed to reduce prostaglandin-mediated uterine contractions. NSAIDs are more effective for primary dysmenorrhea due to their ability to inhibit prostaglandin synthesis.

B) INCORRECT:

Diagnostic laparoscopy is used to evaluate suspected pelvic pathologies, such as endometriosis, not indicated in primary dysmenorrhea with normal ultrasound findings. The patient's symptoms align with prostaglandin-mediated uterine contractions, not structural abnormalities.

C) CORRECT:

Primary dysmenorrhea is characterized by painful menstrual cramps due to increased endometrial prostaglandin production, leading to uterine contractions and ischemia. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) inhibit cyclooxygenase enzymes, reducing prostaglandin synthesis and alleviating pain. The patient's regular menstrual cycles and normal pelvic ultrasound findings support a diagnosis of primary dysmenorrhea, making NSAIDs an appropriate treatment to address the underlying pathophysiology.

Key learning point: NSAIDs are the first-line treatment for primary dysmenorrhea as they reduce prostaglandin production, which alleviates menstrual pain.

D) INCORRECT:

While bed rest may provide temporary comfort, it does not address the prostaglandin-mediated uterine contractions causing primary dysmenorrhea. Active treatment with NSAIDs is more effective in reducing prostaglandin synthesis and alleviating pain.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old college student presents with severe, crampy pelvic pain that begins on the first day of her menses each month. She experiences heavy flow and misses classes monthly due to pain. She has tried over-the-counter ibuprofen without relief. She denies sexual activity and has no significant medical history. Physical examination is normal (see report).
Pelvic ultrasound: Unremarkable
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Diagnostic laparoscopy is used to diagnose conditions like endometriosis, which may not be visible on ultrasound. However, this patient's presentation is consistent with primary dysmenorrhea, characterized by prostaglandin-induced uterine contractions. Invasive procedures are not indicated without other concerning findings.

B) CORRECT:

Primary dysmenorrhea is caused by excessive prostaglandin production during menstruation, leading to uterine contractions and pain. Combined estrogen-progestin regimens thin the endometrial lining, reducing prostaglandin synthesis and alleviating pain. They also regulate the menstrual cycle, decreasing the severity and duration of bleeding. This treatment is effective for patients with dysmenorrhea unresponsive to nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), addressing both hormonal and inflammatory mechanisms.

Key learning point: For severe dysmenorrhea unresponsive to NSAIDs, oral contraceptive pills are an effective next step in management to help regulate the menstrual cycle and reduce pain.

C) INCORRECT:

Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonists reduce estrogen production and are used for estrogen-dependent conditions like endometriosis. They are not suitable for primary dysmenorrhea, which is prostaglandin-mediated. GnRH agonists have significant side effects, such as decreased bone density, making them inappropriate for young patients without endometriosis.

D) INCORRECT:

The levonorgestrel intrauterine device (IUD) reduces menstrual flow and cramping by thinning the endometrium. It is more suitable for women needing long-term contraception or with refractory heavy bleeding. Its invasive placement is less appropriate for patients who deny sexual activity, and non-invasive hormonal management is preferred.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl is brought to your clinic because she has not yet attained menarche. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. She is 168 cm tall and weighs 63 kg; BMI is 22. On examination, she has normal breast development and scant axillary hair. Abdominal examination reveals a firm, nontender left inguinal mass. Pelvic examination shows a blind vaginal pouch. Ultrasonography does not show a uterus or ovaries. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mullerian duct agenesis results in primary amenorrhea, an absent uterus on ultrasound, and a blind vaginal pouch due to vaginal atresia. However, the ovaries would be present. Axillary hair growth would also be normal since primary amenorrhea in patients with Mullerian duct agenesis is the result of an anatomical defect and not a hormonal one.

B) INCORRECT:

A defect in the SRY gene on chromosome Y results in Swyer syndrome, which manifests with primary amenorrhea and absent or atretic ovaries on ultrasound. However, normal development of axillary hair would occur (due to adrenal androgens), and a uterus would be present. Also, breast development would be impaired, and palpable testes would not be present.

C) CORRECT:

Patients with androgen insensitivity syndrome (AIS) are karyotypically male (XY). The Y chromosome results in the formation of the testes (instead of the ovaries) from the undifferentiated fetal gonad. The uterus does not develop because the anti-Mullerian hormone secreted by the testes causes Mullerian duct atresia. However, the genital tubercle in AIS is not responsive to testosterone, so masculinization of the external genitalia does not occur. AIS also results in a failure of the cranial suspensory ligament to regress, meaning the testes remain in the inguinal canal or abdomen instead of the perineal region. Patients are born with female external genitalia and are generally raised as women. At the time of puberty, axillary and pubic hair growth is also absent or decreased since cutaneous androgen receptors lack sensitivity. Breast development occurs despite the absence of ovaries since aromatase in adipose tissue converts androgens produced by the inguinal testes to estradiol.

Hormonal analysis in patients with AIS shows elevated LH levels due to insensitivity of the pituitary gland to androgen and possibly elevated testosterone levels due to stimulation of the Leydig cells by LH. The diagnosis is confirmed by genetic testing, which shows a mutation in the AR gene on chromosome Xq. Patients with complete AIS usually have a female gender identity.

Key learning point: Androgen insensitivity syndrome presents in genetically male (XY) individuals as phenotypic females with normal breast development, absent uterus and ovaries, scant axillary hair, and undescended testes due to end-organ resistance to androgens.

D) INCORRECT:

Five-alpha-reductase deficiency can manifest with primary amenorrhea, female external genitalia with an inguinal testis, and the absence of ovaries and the uterus on ultrasound. However, breast development does not usually occur, and patients would typically have some degree of virilization (e.g., hirsutism, clitoromegaly) at the time of puberty.

E) INCORRECT:

A form of sex chromosomal mosaicism called mixed gonadal dysgenesis (characterized by a 45, XO/XY karyotype) may result in a single inguinal testis, with features of Turner syndrome such as primary amenorrhea and absent or atretic ovaries on ultrasound. Breast development, however, would also be impaired, and a unicornuate uterus or a fallopian tube remnant would be seen on ultrasound on the side without the testicle. Other features would also be seen, such as neck webbing, a low hairline, short stature, shield chest, lymphedema, intellectual disability, congenital heart defects, and/or renal anomalies.
questions.hint: This patient's serum luteinizing hormone (LH) and testosterone levels will both be elevated.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl comes to your clinic because of heavy and prolonged menstrual bleeding. Since menarche one year ago, her periods have been irregular and last 8–9 days. Her last menstrual period was 5 weeks ago and included passage of clots. She has no personal or family history of serious illness and takes no medications. She is at the 50th percentile for height and 20th percentile for weight. Physical examination is normal. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Uterine fibroids are a potential cause of menorrhagia. However, they are more common in women 30–40 years of age and typically manifest with pelvic pressure, pain, and a bulky mass palpable on examination of the uterus. Moreover, this patient lacks risk factors for uterine fibroids such as African American descent, high consumption of alcohol and red meat, and a family history of leiomyoma.

B) CORRECT:

Most cases of menorrhagia within the first two years after menarche are due to an immature hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis and subsequent lack of cyclic endometrial stimulation due to inadequate gonadotropin production. As a result, there are constant, noncyclical levels of estrogen that stimulate endometrial proliferation leading to painless, irregular bleeding, usually including periods of both amenorrhea and prolonged and/or heavy bleeding. Treatment usually includes oral contraceptives or NSAIDs. Other causes for menorrhagia in adolescents include pregnancy and miscarriage, coagulation disorders, pelvic inflammatory disease, intrauterine devices, or underlying structural pelvic pathologies, for which there are no signs in this patient.

Key learning point: In adolescents, heavy and irregular menstrual bleeding is most often due to immature hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis function causing inadequate gonadotropin production and resulting in anovulatory cycles.

C) INCORRECT:

Menorrhagia in endometritis generally occurs in between cycles. Further signs of infection such as fever, lower abdominal pain and tenderness, abnormal discharge, and a history of sexually transmitted diseases are missing in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) most commonly present with oligo- or amenorrhea, and/or irregular cycle length due to ovulatory dysfunction. In addition, high androgen levels in patients with PCOS typically result in hirsutism, acne, and obesity.

E) INCORRECT:

Coagulation disorders (e.g., von Willebrand disease) should be considered in adolescents with heavy menses from menarche onset, severe anemia secondary to menstrual bleeding, and/or a personal or family history of bleeding, easy bruising, and/or epistaxis. This patient lacks a family history and other signs of bleeding diathesis. Furthermore, irregular menstrual periods are not a typical sign of von Willebrand disease.
questions.hint: The most common cause of menorrhagia in postmenarchal adolescents are alternating ovulatory and anovulatory cycles due to an immature hypothalamic–pituitary–ovarian axis.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl comes to your clinic with a 4-month history of episodic pelvic pain radiating to her back and thighs. The pain begins a few hours before her menstrual period and lasts for 2 days. She has been taking ibuprofen, which provides some relief. Her menses have occurred at regular 28-day intervals since menarche at age 12 and last for 5 to 6 days. She is sexually active with two male partners and uses condoms inconsistently. Vital signs are normal. Physical examination is normal. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of her symptoms?

choices.text: Endometrial sloughing and uterine contractions mediated by prostaglandin.
Endometriotic cell implants in the ovaries, fallopian tubes, or cervix.
Ascending infection of the uterus, fallopian tubes, ovaries, or surrounding tissue.
Endometrial tissue within the uterine wall.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A fluid-filled sac within the ovary would be present in patients with an ovarian cyst. While complications of ovarian cysts (e.g., ruptured ovarian cyst) can also cause pelvic pain, the pain would usually be severe, with a sudden onset, rather than episodic and associated with menses. Uncomplicated cysts are usually asymptomatic and an incidental finding on ultrasound.

B) CORRECT:

Primary dysmenorrhea is the most common gynecological complaint among adolescent females. The condition is most likely caused by an increased production of endometrial prostaglandin (PG) F2α. PGF2α causes dysrhythmic uterine contractions and consequently abdominal pain and uterine ischemia (which leads to endometrial sloughing). The accompanying symptoms of primary dysmenorrhea (e.g., headache, diarrhea, fatigue, nausea) are also believed to be mediated by PGF2α. NSAIDs such as ibuprofen are the first-line treatment for primary dysmenorrhea since they inhibit PG synthesis. Patients that do not respond to NSAIDs should be treated with oral contraceptive pills, which decrease PG levels by suppressing ovulation.

Key learning point: Primary dysmenorrhea is caused by increased endometrial prostaglandin production, leading to painful uterine contractions during menstruation; NSAIDs are first-line treatment.

C) INCORRECT:

Endometriotic cell implants in the ovaries, fallopian tubes, or cervix are found in patients with endometriosis, which can cause secondary dysmenorrhea. However, patients with secondary dysmenorrhea due to endometriosis typically present with rectovaginal tenderness, adnexal masses, dyspareunia, and pre- or post-menstrual bleeding. Moreover, patients with endometriosis usually become symptomatic after adolescence (20–40 years).

D) INCORRECT:

Ascending infection of the uterus, fallopian tubes, ovaries, or surrounding tissue is the cause of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). Although this patient's sexual history puts her at risk of PID, patients would typically present with progressive lower abdominal or pelvic pain, cervical motion or adnexal tenderness, fever, nausea, dyspareunia, and vaginal discharge. Episodic pelvic pain that lasts only a few days and is associated with menstruation is not typical for PID and rather indicates primary dysmenorrhea.

E) INCORRECT:

Endometrial tissue within the uterine wall is found in patients with adenomyosis, which can cause secondary dysmenorrhea and manifest with episodic pain associated with menses. However, adenomyosis is more common in women between 40–50 years of age and is typically associated with menorrhagia. Also, a pelvic exam often shows an enlarged, boggy, symmetric uterus.
questions.hint: Episodic lower abdominal pain shortly before menstruation in an adolescent with a normal physical exam suggests primary dysmenorrhea.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, comes to your clinic because she has not had a menstrual period for 4 months. She had a spontaneous abortion 10 months ago. Her medical history includes an abnormal Pap smear treated with loop electrosurgical excision 2 years ago. She is a competitive triathlon athlete and has been training for an upcoming long-distance triathlon. Her BMI is 18. Physical examination, including pelvic examination, is normal. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of her amenorrhea?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intrauterine adhesions can occur following trauma to the endometrium during uterine procedures or prolonged intrauterine inflammation and manifest with secondary amenorrhea and pregnancy loss. While this patient has a history of a loop electrosurgical excision procedure, intrauterine adhesions are most commonly seen in patients after uterine dilation and curettage. Moreover, patients with uterine adhesions typically experience abnormal uterine bleeding and pelvic pain, which is not seen here. In addition, this patient has no history (of features) that would suggest prolonged intrauterine inflammation (e.g., pelvic inflammatory disease, chorioamnionitis, endometritis).

B) INCORRECT:

Tumoral production of prolactin is found in patients with a pituitary prolactinoma, which can cause secondary amenorrhea due to suppression of GnRH. However, prolactinomas also manifest with galactorrhea and mass effect (e.g., bilateral hemianopsia, headaches), none of which are seen here.

C) INCORRECT:

Anabolic steroid abuse, which is often seen in professional athletes, can cause secondary amenorrhea due to suppression of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis. However, affected patients typically also present with signs of virilization (e.g., voice deepening, hirsutism, male-pattern hair loss, increased muscle mass, clitoromegaly), none of which are seen here.

D) INCORRECT:

Primary ovarian insufficiency (POI) can develop in a 28-year-old female patient and manifest with secondary amenorrhea due to follicular depletion. However, POI also manifests with vaginal dryness, night sweats, hot flashes, dyspareunia, and irritability, none of which are seen in this patient.

E) CORRECT:

Functional hypothalamic amenorrhea (FHA) is typically caused by strenuous physical exercise, reduced caloric intake, and/or excessive stress, which leads to decreased leptin and increased cortisol with a consequent decrease in the pulsatile release of GnRH from the hypothalamus. The decreased pulsatile release of GnRH leads to a decrease in FSH and LH secretion, and therefore, a decrease in the production of estrogen, which inhibits normal ovulation and causes amenorrhea. FHA is a diagnosis of exclusion; other causes of amenorrhea, such as pregnancy, primary ovarian insufficiency, hypothyroidism, and hyperprolactinemia must first be ruled out. Treatment usually consists of lifestyle changes (e.g., stress reduction, improving nutrition, increasing BMI > 19 kg/m2). Patients can also be offered pulsatile GnRH or gonadotropin therapy to induce ovulation.

Key learning point: Functional hypothalamic amenorrhea is caused by decreased pulsatile GnRH release due to stress, excessive exercise, or low caloric intake, leading to reduced FSH, LH, and estrogen production and resulting in amenorrhea.
questions.hint: Women of reproductive age who are underweight or do not consume enough calories (often competitive athletes) can develop amenorrhea due to hypothalamic hypogonadism.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 3-month history of dyspareunia and vaginal dryness. She also reports intermittent hot flashes and fatigue during this period. Over the past year, her menstrual cycles have become irregular, and her last menstrual period was more than 6 months ago. She has a history of acute lymphoblastic leukemia in childhood, which has remained in remission. On pelvic examination, the cervix and vagina appear atrophic. A urinary pregnancy test is negative. A progestin challenge test is performed and shows no withdrawal bleeding. Further evaluation is most likely to reveal which one of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Increased TSH is seen in primary hypothyroidism, which can also manifest with secondary amenorrhea and fatigue. However, this patient lacks other typical features of hypothyroidism, such as weight gain, cold intolerance, dry skin, constipation.

B) INCORRECT:

Decreased luteinizing hormone (LH) levels are seen in hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, which can be congenital (e.g., Kallmann syndrome) or acquired (e.g., excessive exercise, reduced caloric intake, stress, pituitary lesions). While cases of acquired hypogonadotropic hypogonadism cause secondary amenorrhea, the absence of a history of excessive exercise or eating disorders and the presence of vaginal dryness and hot flashes (which are atypical for these conditions) make hypogonadotropic hypogonadism unlikely. Furthermore, this patient's presentation is highly suggestive of primary ovarian insufficiency, in which the loss of feedback inhibition of estrogen on gonadotropin (e.g., FSH, LH) secretion results in elevated serum levels of these hormones.

C) INCORRECT:

Testosterone levels and other androgens are usually increased in cases of polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS), which can also manifest with secondary amenorrhea. However, this patient lacks other typical manifestations of PCOS, such as hirsutism, acne vulgaris, obesity, or metabolic syndrome. Hot flashes and vaginal dryness are not typically seen in PCOS.

D) INCORRECT:

Decreased estrogen levels in ovarian failure result in increased follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) levels due to the loss of feedback inhibition of estrogen on gonadotropin secretion. As a result, the ratio of FSH to estrogen would be high in a patient with suspected primary ovarian failure.

E) CORRECT:

Primary ovarian insufficiency manifests with decreased estrogen levels as well as elevated FSH levels due to loss of feedback inhibition from estrogen on gonadotropin secretion from the anterior pituitary.

While most cases of POI are idiopathic, known causes include treatment with radiation and/or chemotherapy (this patient has a history of acute lymphoblastic leukemia during childhood) and certain genetic disorders (e.g., Turner syndrome, fragile X syndrome).

Key learning point: Primary ovarian insufficiency is characterized by decreased estrogen and elevated FSH levels due to loss of negative feedback on the pituitary.
questions.hint: This patient presents with secondary amenorrhea and features of low estrogen levels (hot flashes, vaginal dryness) before the age of 40, which should raise concern for primary ovarian insufficiency.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman comes to your clinic because she has not had a menstrual period for the past 6 months. During this time, she has experienced frequent headaches, difficulty sleeping, and increased sweating. She reports no weight changes. Over the past year, her menses were irregular, occurring every 30 to 45 days with light flow. She has a history of two successful cesarean deliveries at ages 28 and 32, and has two children. She is sexually active with her husband and they do not use contraception. Vital signs are normal. Physical examination is normal. Laboratory studies show low estrogen and elevated FSH and LH levels. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The low T3/T4 levels associated with primary hypothyroidism cause a compensatory increase of thyroid-stimulating hormone and thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH). TRH stimulates prolactin production, which then leads to a suppression of LH and FSH. Therefore, primary hypothyroidism can indeed cause amenorrhea, but it would be associated with low LH and FSH levels. Additionally, other typical features, such as fatigue, weight gain, cold intolerance, dry skin, and hair loss, would be expected.

B) INCORRECT:

Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) can manifest with amenorrhea and mood changes. However, other typical features of PCOS, such as hirsutism, acne, and weight gain are not seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Hyperprolactinemia causes amenorrhea and is associated with signs of mass effect (headache). However, it would also manifest with other symptoms such as galactorrhea, signs of hypogonadism, and possibly bitemporal hemianopsia. Moreover, patients with hyperprolactinemia normally present with high prolactin levels and low FSH and LH levels.

D) CORRECT:

Primary ovarian insufficiency (POI), also known as premature ovarian failure, is inadequate ovarian function in women below the age of 40 years. Patients with POI typically present with hypergonadotropic hypogonadism (high FSH and LH levels, low estrogen levels) and climacteric features (headache, impaired sleep, increased sweating) followed by amenorrhea. POI also explains why this patient has not conceived again despite not using contraception. Treatment of POI includes hormone replacement therapy.

Key learning point: Premature ovarian failure (primary ovarian insufficiency) presents in women under 40 with amenorrhea, low estrogen, and elevated FSH and LH, reflecting hypergonadotropic hypogonadism and menopausal symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

Pregnancy should be suspected in any woman of reproductive age who presents with amenorrhea and is otherwise healthy. However, pregnancy would be associated with low FSH and LH levels, as well as high prolactin levels. Moreover, in pregnancy, a suprapubic mass (the gravid uterus) would be palpable by the 4th month of amenorrhea.
questions.hint: Low estrogen levels in conjunction with elevated FSH and LH levels in a patient with absent menses for 6 months (following irregular cycles) are consisetent with secondary amenorrhea.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman with no significant medical history comes to your clinic because her menses have become heavier and more painful over the past 3 years. She reports that her periods previously lasted 5 days, but now she bleeds for 7 days and passes clots the size of oranges for 4 of those days. Her menstrual cramping responds well to ibuprofen. She does not feel tired or lightheaded. Vital signs are normal. On bimanual examination, you find a mildly enlarged uterus without distinct mass lesions. Which one of the following tests is most appropriate to evaluate her condition?

choices.text: Measurement of estradiol and follicle-stimulating hormone levels.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Estradiol and follicle-stimulating hormone levels would help differentiate perimenopause from primary ovarian insufficiency, but measuring these levels is not indicated for the evaluation of abnormal uterine bleeding.

B) CORRECT:

The normal menstrual cycle lasts 21 to 35 days; the normal duration of flow is about 5 days with less than 80 mL of blood lost. Abnormal uterine bleeding is bleeding that is abnormal in flow or cycle. The most common causes of abnormal uterine bleeding include anatomical uterine pathologies, such as endometrial polyps, adenomyosis, uterine leiomyomas, endometrial hyperplasia, and endometrial carcinoma.

The optimal approach to investigating abnormal uterine bleeding has not been established for a woman with a normal-size uterus; however, a woman with an enlarged uterus should undergo imaging. A pelvic ultrasound is optimal because it provides better and more cost-effective imaging than a pelvic MRI.

Key learning point: The most appropriate test to evaluate a premenopausal woman with recent menorrhagia and an enlarged uterus is pelvic ultrasound.

C) INCORRECT:

Hysteroscopy is appropriate for women with suspected intrauterine pathology where a biopsy is indicated. Hysteroscopy would not be performed before imaging in a 37-year-old woman with abnormal uterine bleeding.

D) INCORRECT:

The optimal approach to investigating abnormal uterine bleeding in a woman with a normal-sized uterus has not been clearly established. However, in cases of an enlarged uterus, imaging is recommended. A different imaging modality is preferred over MRI due to its superior and more cost-effective results.

E) INCORRECT:

Endometrial biopsy is not indicated for a premenopausal woman with regular menstrual cycles. Endometrial biopsy is generally used to investigate dysfunctional uterine bleeding in women who are at least 45 years old, women with a history of exposure to unopposed estrogen, and women with an abnormally thickened endometrium on pelvic ultrasound.
questions.hint: Passing of blood clots larger than 2–3 cm is a clinical indicator for heavy menstrual bleeding.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman comes to your clinic because she has not had a menstrual period for 6 months. She is a competitive runner and has been training heavily for the past year in preparation for upcoming races. She has no family or personal history of serious illness. She has not been sexually active for the past 9 months. Her temperature is 36.9°C, pulse is 51/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 106/67 mm Hg. Her BMI is 18. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of her amenorrhea?

choices.text: Poor synthetic response of ovarian cells to circulating LH and FSH.
Increased LH release and increased ovarian androgen production.
Decreased frequency of GnRH release from the hypothalamus.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Poor synthetic response of ovarian cells to circulating LH and FSH is seen in patients with primary ovarian insufficiency. While patients with this condition will ultimately also develop secondary amenorrhea, they initially have intermittent ovulatory cycles and therefore irregular menstrual periods. In addition, patients often present with typical symptoms of estrogen deficiency such as hot flashes and vaginal dryness. Furthermore, the condition more frequently occurs after the age of 30.

B) INCORRECT:

Increased LH release and increased ovarian androgen production is seen in patients with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). Although PCOS is the most common reproductive disorder in women and can also cause amenorrhea, patients are obese rather than underweight and often have acne or hirsutism.

C) INCORRECT:

Autoimmune destruction of thyroid cells is seen in patients with Hashimoto thyroiditis. Although hypothyroidism is also a potential cause of amenorrhea that should certainly be considered, this patient has no other symptoms that would suggest this underlying condition (e.g., weight gain, fatigue, cold intolerance). Although hypothyroidism is not the most likely cause of this patient's amenorrhea, TSH levels should be measured in all women with secondary amenorrhea to rule out this condition.

D) CORRECT:

Functional hypothalamic amenorrhea (FHA) is a common cause of amenorrhea in underweight women of reproductive age. FHA can be caused by a variety of factors, such as excessive exercise, reduced caloric intake, or emotional stress. In response to the decreased energy availability in these states, the body regulates the reproductive potential down by decreasing the frequency of GnRH release from the hypothalamus, which subsequently leads to decreased secretion of gonadotropins (FSH and LH), anovulation, and secondary amenorrhea.

Key learning point: Functional hypothalamic amenorrhea in athletes is caused by decreased GnRH secretion due to low energy availability from excessive exercise or caloric restriction, leading to reduced FSH and LH, anovulation, and amenorrhea.

E) INCORRECT:

Increased prolactin secretion is found in patients with a pituitary prolactinoma. The condition can also cause secondary amenorrhea, which is also seen in this patient, sometimes in conjunction with galactorrhea. However, this patient's history of excessive exercise and her low BMI make a different cause more likely. Although a prolactinoma is not the most likely cause of this patient's amenorrhea, prolactin levels should be measured in all women with secondary amenorrhea to rule out hyperprolactinemia.
questions.hint: Competitive female athletes often present with amenorrhea, which forms part of the “female athlete triad.”

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl comes to your clinic reporting intermittent episodes of sadness and irritability over the past 5 months. These episodes occur every 4–5 weeks and are associated with abdominal pain, bloating, and headaches. Her menstrual cycles are regular, occurring every 31 days, and her last period was 4 weeks ago. She denies excessive worry or difficulty concentrating. She plays on her high school soccer team and attends practice 4–5 times per week. Her BMI is at the 21st percentile. Vital signs are normal. Abdominal examination reveals mild distention without tenderness, guarding, or rebound. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with anorexia nervosa typically have low body weight and often engage in demanding physical activities, both of which are seen in this patient. However, patients with anorexia nervosa typically have a history of significant deliberate weight reduction, fear of weight gain, and excessive concern about weight and body shape, none of which is present here. Moreover, anorexia nervosa is associated with menstrual irregularities, while this patient has regular menses. In addition, anorexia nervosa is defined by a BMI < 10th percentile in pediatric patients; this's patient's BMI is at the 21st percentile.

B) INCORRECT:

Mittelschmerz manifests with cyclic abdominal pain, which this patient has. However, mittelschmerz is not associated with mood disturbances or headaches. Moreover, the time frame is not consistent with mittelschmerz; because this patient had her last menses 4 weeks ago, she most likely already ovulated.

C) CORRECT:

Headaches, abdominal pain and bloating, and mood disturbances that occur every 4–5 weeks suggest premenstrual syndrome (PMS). Symptoms of PMS are cyclical and can start around 5 days before and resolve within 4 days after the onset of menstruation. The diagnosis of PMS requires a clear pattern of symptoms associated with menstrual periods, for which maintaining a menstrual diary is useful. This patient presents with irritability and abdominal distention, which, given the fact that her last menstrual period was 4 weeks ago, is consistent with another episode of PMS. Preexisting endocrine (e.g., thyroid disorders) and psychiatric (e.g., major depressive disorder) conditions should be ruled out before diagnosing PMS.

See “Comparison of PMS and PMDD” table.

Key learning point: Premenstrual syndrome is characterized by cyclical physical and mood symptoms that occur in the luteal phase and resolve with the onset of menstruation.

D) INCORRECT:

Premenstrual dysphoric disorder (PMDD) manifests with cyclical mood disturbances, abdominal pain, bloating, and headaches, all of which are associated with menstrual periods. However, PMDD is associated with more severe psychological symptoms including hopelessness, anger, self-deprecating thoughts, and anxiety, which cause significant distress and interference in daily activities (e.g., work, school, social activities, relationships).

E) INCORRECT:

Major depressive disorder (MDD) manifests with depressed mood and irritability. This patient is at increased risk of developing MDD, as her mother has been diagnosed with depression. However, while this patient's symptoms seem to be cyclical, patients with MDD present with constant symptoms. Moreover, MDD usually manifests with additional features such as sleep disturbances, anhedonia, fatigue, diminished concentration, or impaired functioning in daily activities, none of which is seen here.
questions.hint: Keeping a diary could provide a valuable clue to this patient's diagnosis.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl is brought to your clinic by her mother because she has not yet attained menarche. She has no history of serious illness. Her height and weight are at the 50th percentile. On examination, there is no glandular breast tissue and no pubic hair development. Pelvic examination is normal. The remainder of the examination is normal. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:
